Let the weapons be silenced; let the cry for peace be heard from the poor, from the people, from the children!

US President Joe Biden has told Israel's prime minister it "appears" a hospital blast in Gaza was "done by the other team".

Israel said the blast on Tuesday evening was caused by a rocket misfired by Palestinian militants. Hamas, Palestinian authorities, and other countries blame Israel for the explosion.

Hundreds of people have been killed in the the explosion at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, health officials said.

Biden said he visited Israel to show where the US stands in the conflict.

Tap the link in our bio to read the latest on the president‚Äôs arrival in Israel.

(üì∑ Reuters)

Six months of war between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces have plunged the country into "one of the worst humanitarian nightmares in recent history," killing up to 9,000 people and displacing over 5 million. The United Nations says least 25 million people in Sudan are also in need of urgent humanitarian relief.

The healthcare situation is also dire as many medical facilities in conflict areas have been shuttered. Human rights groups have condemned the ongoing targeting and killing of civilians and journalists.

Il dolore diventa ogni giorno pi√π grande e le vittime innocenti dell‚Äôospedale di Gaza suscitano il mio pi√π profondo sdegno e devono scandalizzare le coscienze di tutti quelli che hanno il potere di decidere; non solo me e noi spettatori sconvolti e attoniti da tutto questo orrore.
Il mio pensiero va ai familiari delle vittime.
E mi unisco con tutto il cuore e con tutta la forza possibile al segretario generale dell‚ÄôOnu Antonio Guterres che ha chiesto un immediato cessate il fuoco nella regione.
Ha perfettamente ragione quando afferma che gli ospedali e il personale medico sono protetti dal diritto internazionale.
Cos√¨ come ha ragione l‚ÄôUnione Europea che ha ricordato e sottolineato che il limite sono le regole del diritto internazionale.
Tutti devono rispettare le regole del diritto internazionale e del diritto umanitario.
Non smetter√≤ di dirlo e non smetter√≤ di dire basta alla violenza!

The pain of conflict becomes greater every day, and the innocent victims of the Gaza hospital attack have aroused the deepest outrage and must shock the consciences of all those who have the power to take and make decisions that can end this suffering. I am not alone in being a shocked and astonished onlooker at all of this horror.
However, my thoughts now are with the families of the innocent victims.
And I wholeheartedly join to depth of my being, the UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres who has called for an immediate ceasefire in the region.
He is categorically correct that hospitals, patients and medical personnel are protected by international law.
As is the European Union correct when it reminded and stressed to the world that the the rules of international law set the limit and must be respected.
No one and nothing is exempt from abiding by the rules of international law and humanitarian law.
I will never stop saying this and I will never stop saying no more violence!

German club Mainz 05 suspended Dutch forward Anwar El Ghazi (@elghazi21) for a social media post about the conflict that the Bundesliga club felt was ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù.

‚ÄúMainz 05 respects that there are different perspectives on the complex Middle East conflict that has been going on for decades,‚Äù the club said in a statement posted on X on Tuesday.

‚ÄúEl Ghazi took a position on the ongoing conflict in the Middle East that was deemed unacceptable and the club clearly distances itself from the content of the post as it does not reflect the values ‚Äã‚Äãof our club.‚Äù

Dutch international El Ghazi made the comments in a ‚Äúsince-deleted‚Äù post on social media on Sunday night, Mainz said.

The club did not provide further details about what El Ghazi had written in the deleted post but said, ‚ÄúPrior to making this decision, the club and the player had engaged in an in-depth discussion.‚Äù

It did not indicate how long the suspension could last.

A senior official at the US State Department issued his resignation on Wednesday evening, citing the Biden administration's approach to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

"Let me be clear: Hamas' attack on Israel was not just a monstrosity; it was a monstrosity of monstrosities," Josh Paul said in a letter, which was posted on X by Brian Finucane, a senior adviser at Crisis Group.

"But I believe to the core of my soul that the response Israel is taking, and with it the American support both for that response, and for the status quo of the occupation, will only lead to more and deeper suffering for both the Israeli and the Palestinian people - and is not in the long term American interest.

Paul worked for more than 10 ears in the State Department's Political-Military Affairs bureau, which is in charge of approving arms transfers to other countries.

Biden has been clear in stating that he will support
Israel unequivocally as it takes action against
Palestinian armed groups in Gaza, which on 7 October launched a surprise attack on Israel.

The war has so far killed more than 3,000 Palestinians, including around 1,000 children and 1,000 women, while also killing more than 1,400 Israelis.

MEE reported last week that the White House's phrasing of any calls for a ceasefire were "repugnant", sending a chilling message to progressive lawmakers and anti-war activists.

The Biden administration is currently drafting a major foreign aid bill that would include $10b for Israel. In addition to the aid package, the US has also deployed two carrier strike groups to the Eastern Mediterranean and has readied 2,000 American troops to be deployed in order to support Israel, as the country readies for a ground invasion of Gaza.

"I cannot work in support of a set of major policy decisions, including rushing more arms to one side of the conflict, that I believe to be shortsighted, destructive, unjust, and contradictory to the very values that we publicly espouse, Paul said further in his letter.

These signs were mentioned by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in various Hadith (sayings and actions of the Prophet). Some of the minor signs include:

1. Widespread dishonesty and corruption.
2. A decrease in religious knowledge and practice.

President Joe Biden cautioned the Israeli government to avoid being 'consumed' by 'rage' in his remarks from Tel Aviv on October 18.

Biden traveled to Israel to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu amid the growing Israel-Gaza conflict. During his remarks, Biden referenced 9/11 and admitted that the United States was enraged after the terrorist attack and 'made mistakes' while seeking justice. 

'But I caution this while you feel that rage: Don't be consumed by it,' Biden said. 'After 9/11, we were enraged in the United States. While we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes ... I know the choices are never clear or easy for leadership. There's always cost. But it requires being deliberate. It requires asking very hard questions. It requires clarity about the objectives and an honest assessment about whether the path you're on will achieve those objectives.'

Biden didn't specify what mistakes, but many have assumed he was alluding to the U.S.'s invasion of Iraq after 9/11, which he supported as a senator at the time, but has since said was a mistake. The Iraq War destabilized the region for years and led to an enormous loss of civilian life, estimated to be in the hundreds of thousands.

Critics argued that Biden's warning came off as somewhat hollow, given his administration‚Äôs substantial military aid to Israel. His remarks glossed over the stark power disparity between Israel and Palestine and failed to sufficiently address the humanitarian crisis unfolding in real time, they said.

In his address, Biden went on to urge the Israeli war cabinet to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance to civilians in Gaza, predicated on inspections to ensure the aid bypasses Hamas. He stressed, 'The vast majority of Palestinians are not Hamas. Hamas does not represent the Palestinian people.' Following this appeal, Israel agreed to allow the entry of aid into Gaza.

However, detractors pointed out that these stringent conditions on aid might inadvertently perpetuate the cycle of violence and hamper efforts to achieve a sustainable cease-fire and lasting peace.

Crowds of demonstrators gathered in Washington Square Park on Tuesday amid the ongoing conflict in Israel and Gaza.

The demonstrations started after the news of a devastating explosion at the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City that killed hundreds of people. Anger over the deadly blast also incited protests in cities across the Middle East that stretched into Wednesday morning, bringing defiant crowds to embassies and consulates of countries that demonstrators said were complicit in the humanitarian crisis facing Palestinians in Gaza.

On Wednesday, American and Israeli intelligence said early evidence showed that the deadly explosion was caused by an errant rocket fired by Palestinian fighters.

This morning, President Biden arrived in Tel Aviv to stand in solidarity with the people of Israel and show his steadfast support following Hamas‚Äôs appalling terrorist attack, as well as consult on next steps.

President Biden met with Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss the situation on the ground, objectives in the days ahead, and what Israel needs to defend itself from terrorism.
 
In discussions, President Biden also made it clear that we do not want to see this conflict widen, deepen, or expand.

The leaders also discussed the worsening humanitarian situation in Gaza. Civilians caught in the middle urgently need food, electricity, water, medicine, and shelter. President Biden asked the Israeli Cabinet to allow the delivery of humanitarian assistance, and they agreed.

President Biden and Prime Minister Netanyahu also discussed the hostage situation as the U.S. continues to work to get these hostages out. President Biden‚Äôs top priority is the safe return of American hostages.

The two leaders will remain in contact over the coming days as the United States continues to stand with the people of Israel. 

President Biden also noted that the world is watching. Israel, like the United States and other democracies, has a value set, and they're looking to see what we're going to do.

Is ChatGPT biased against Palestinians?

British author and journalist Mona Chalabi posed two questions about the Israel-Palestine conflict to ChatGPT, an artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot.

The answers it provided indicated a clear bias and were shared online to show AI‚Äôs difference in tone and position when asked an objective question about Israelis and Palestinians.

‚ÄúChatGPT, like all artificial intelligence, has been taught by us. We have a responsibility to be thoughtful about how we use our words and to think critically,‚Äù Chalabi says.

‚ÄúAll people deserve justice. But real justice can‚Äôt be had if ‚Äòit‚Äôs complicated‚Äô for some of us but not for others,‚Äù she added

We also asked ChatGPT a couple of questions. Here‚Äôs how the AI-powered tech responded.

The Iranian-backed Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) terror organization was responsible for an explosion at the Ahli Baptist Hospital in Gaza City, due to a misfired rocket intended to kill Israeli civilians, according to the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) @idf . 

The explosion, which reportedly killed hundreds of people, sparked outrage, with Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas pulling out of a meeting Wednesday with U.S. President Joe Biden over the issue. Biden has backed Israel‚Äôs war of self-defense against the Hamas terror group, which rules Gaza and which killed over 1,400 Israelis in a massive terror attack on October 7.

Hamas and critics of Israel rushed to blame an Israeli airstrike. News wires, like the Getty photo service, published unproven claims Israel had ‚Äúattack[ed]‚Äù the hospital, citing the ‚ÄúGaza Health Ministry,‚Äù which is run by Hamas. But Israel, noting that it does not target hospitals, said an errant Palestinian rocket was a likely cause, later confirming that analysis. As Breitbart News has noted, a significant portion of Palestinian casualties in previous conflicts in Gaza have been caused by misfired rockets launched by Palestinian terror groups ‚Äî up to one-third of Palestinian casualties in a conflict last year.

Rp: @sirianajanine: ‚ÄúBut why is a preschool teacher posting about Palestine? That‚Äôs so political.‚Äù

Kindly see yourself out, because you‚Äôre most likely a ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù person who doesn‚Äôt say this when I speak out against every other injustice that affects marginalized and oppressed peoples. 

The story of Palestine is the first injustice and struggle for liberation that I ever learned about. üáµüá∏ It‚Äôs what brought me to my work. 

In the past, Palestinians and their allies have been silenced and threatened for speaking out about the colonization of their land. 

In fact, until recently, people and governments would falsely call you antisemitic if you even said the name ‚ÄúPalestine‚Äù, and not ‚ÄúPalestinian territories.‚Äù This was intentionally meant to suppress solidarity and the truth about Palestine, while it also meant that antisemitism (a very present and dangerous form of bigotry against Jewish people) was misrepresented as criticizing Israel‚Äôs violent establishment and ethnic cleansing. 

And with so much false information and deflection that continues to frame Palestine as a ‚Äútwo-sided, complicated, religious conflict‚Äù, I had to speak out and share my lifetime of knowledge and research on the Palestinian struggle for justice. 

Please amplify Palestinian voices. Please listen to Jewish voices when they stand in solidarity and tell Israel to stop colonizing Palestine in the name of their religion. Israeli genocide does not represent Judaism. Justice for one is justice for all. 

I invite you to continue reading Palestinian stories and speaking with your children about Palestine, the way you do with all forms of racism and oppression. 

You are welcome to ask me questions to help you unlearn the anti-Palestinian and orientalist rhetoric we‚Äôve all been taught. You are NOT welcome to attack me by falsely claiming my solidarity with Palestinians is antisemitic. 

There is hope. There is light. Freedom begins with knowledge.

‚ÄúThe massacre brought our health system to its knees.‚Äù

A doctor at Gaza‚Äôs al-Ahli Arab hospital has described the ‚Äúsurreal‚Äù and ‚Äúhorrifying‚Äù scenes he witnessed in the aftermath of an Israeli air strike that killed at least 471 Palestinians there last night.

‚ÄúThe brutality and the nature of the injuries we saw were something we had never witnessed in any attack on Gaza before,‚Äù Mohammed Gniem told Middle East Eye, after an Israeli bomb ripped through the hospital, leaving the bodies of the dead and wounded in its wake.

The massacre marks the single greatest loss of life in the ongoing conflict, which has seen at least 3,000 Palestinians killed in Gaza and the West Bank, and 1,400 people killed in Israel. Israeli siege and air strikes on Gaza have continued since 7 October, following a surprise Hamas-led attack on Israel.

Thousands of displaced Palestinians were sheltering in the courtyards of al-Ahli hospital in Gaza City, assuming that they were in a safe place. Many of those are now dead or seriously wounded.

One eyewitness, who did not wish to be named, told MEE that Israel ‚Äúthreatened to bomb the hospital during the first days of the attack, but we never thought they would actually do it‚Äù.

Gniem said that the massacre had shattered Gaza‚Äôs health system.

‚ÄúBefore the massacre, our hospital was already on the brink. Rooms were filled with those healing from previous massacres, and every corridor was filled with displaced people who sought a safe place to stay,‚Äù the doctor said.

‚ÄúTry picturing a hospital already at capacity,‚Äù Gniem said. ‚ÄúThen add an influx of 500 of the injured and deceased,‚Äù he told MEE.

The doctor said that he had seen the bellies of children ripped open, ‚Äútheir remains were coming out of their bodies. All these injuries came while the staff were exhausted and the hospital was full.

‚ÄúIn a facility already stretched thin, our staff had to make do, treating those injured wherever space permitted, on the bare ground, with whatever scant supplies we had left,‚Äù Gniem said.

‚úçÔ∏è: Aseel Mousa, Ahmed Dremly and Maha Hussaini in Gaza Strip, occupied Palestine

My older son called me yesterday. Recent events in Israel and Gaza have had him thinking about the 9/11 attacks. He asked me what they were like for me, a then 20 year old who had given birth to him just 11 days earlier.

I tried to explain the confusion and fear. The way that I couldn't fully wrap my head around what I was seeing on my television screen. I remember feeling upside down sudden. I remember holding my baby and wondering what world I had brought him into.

But what I remember even more clearly was what the US did in response. I remember sitting in the break room at work as Bush talked about a "war on terror" and I remember thinking clearly - having pretty good  knowledge from my studies of how US global colonialist interventions and support of oppressive regimes had been a major driver of the cycles of violence that the terror attacks were a part of. 

I remember wanting to get home to hug my baby so desperately. I just stood there at work, no sick time left after maternity leave, absorbing the knowledge that my baby, and millions of other babies would be the ones to pay for our deliberately uninformed rage, our violence, our greed, our bigotry.
And so yesterday, my baby, now two years older than I was on the day of those attacks, my baby who like so many of his generation has only known these wars that are still happening, has only known the Middle East as a place of conflict, and who is still one of the lucky ones because he was born in the place doing the killing and not the place where a million were killed - he asked me what it was like then, and I couldn't think of a way to explain that every day is still that day and worse. Because we didn't stop it. We didn't stop the nightmare that was right before us, and now we can't wake up.

Please. Please let's not let this happen again.

A HISTORY OF SILENCE: A Melbourne man says he‚Äôs learned from past mistakes as he opts to stay out of the social media discourse surrounding the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas.

In previous flare ups between Israel and Palestine, Naarm boy Wesley Talbot was quick to show his support for Palestine but that lead to conflict between his old Camberwell schoolmates who didn‚Äôt see it the way he did.

‚ÄúTheir parents called my parents, it was messy but that was a while ago and my old friends were happy to ‚Äòeducate‚Äô me and move on,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúSo despite there being, you know, clear violations of international law and abhorrent criminal acts committed upon‚Ä¶ actually, I‚Äôm going to stop myself there. Members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) should impose an oil embargo and other sanctions on Israel and expel all Israeli ambassadors, Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian said on Wednesday.

An urgent meeting of the OIC is taking place in the Saudi city of Jeddah to discuss the escalating Israeli-Palestinian conflict, after a blast at a Gaza hospital late on Tuesday killed large numbers of Palestinians.
"The foreign minister calls for an immediate and complete embargo on Israel by Islamic countries, including oil sanctions, in addition to expelling Israeli ambassadors if relations with the Zionist regime have been established," the Iranian foreign ministry said in a statement.

Amirabdollahian also called for the formation of a team of Islamic lawyers to document potential war crimes committed by Israel in Gaza.

Hundreds of San Francisco high school students and students from across the country walked out of classes Wednesday to protest ongoing violence in Gaza and call for an immediate ceasefire.

The walkout led by Arab Youth Organizing came after an explosion at a hospital where the Hamas-run Health Ministry says at least 500 people were killed, though the event was conceived of earlier by a San Francisco high school student whose family is from Gaza, organizers said. More than 3,000 Palestinians have been killed in the conflict, including over 1,100 children, according to organizers.

A couple of hundred students marched along Francisco Street before turning onto Van Ness Avenue and walking toward Bay Street from Galileo High School. At the head of the line, a student held the Palestinian flag. Other students chanted, "From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free."

The White House says current intelligence shows that Israel was ‚Äúnot responsible‚Äù for the explosion at a Gaza hospital, but information is still being collected. Hamas blames Israel.

Students are demanding an end to U.S. aid to Israel, arguing the funding enables Israel's military strikes on Gaza. The U.S. provides about $3.8 billion a year in aid to Israel.

Organizers held a news conference outside San Francisco City Hall at 10 a.m. ahead of the planned walkout. Speakers included local officials, religious leaders, labor leaders and community organizers.

A rare Roman-era mosaic is uncovered during the excavation of an old building in Syria .

RASTAN, Syria ‚Äîin 2022 Syria uncovered a large intact mosaic that dates back to the Roman era, describing it Wednesday as the most important archaeological discovery since the country's conflict began 11 years ago.

Journalists were shown the mosaic in the central town of Rastan near Homs, Syria's third largest city.

The mosaic, at 120 square meters (around 1,300 square feet), was found in an old building that Syria's General Directorate of Antiquities and Museums had been excavating.

Lebanese and Syrian businessmen from the neighboring country's Nabu Museum bought the property that dates back to the 4th century and donated it to the Syrian state.

Each panel was filled with square-shaped, small colorful stones measuring about half an inch on each side.

Dr. Humam Saad, the associate director of excavation and archaeological research at the directorate, said among the scenes the mosaic shows is a rare portrayal of Ancient Amazon warriors in Roman mythology.

"What is in front of us is a discovery that is rare on a global scale," Saad told The Associated Press, adding that the images are "rich in details," and includes scenes from the Trojan War between the Greeks and Trojans.

In Ancient Greek and Roman mythology, demigod hero Hercules slayed Hippolyta, queen of the Amazons, in one of his 12 labors.

Source : NPR website

While we all would like conflicts to be minimized, avoided, or resolved by peaceful means, the reality is that sometimes some people are so maddened by their hunger for power, by their memories of grievance and the cravings for vengeance, or by the extreme ideologies that they essentially become Wicked, and that means that there is no talking sense with them.

In fact, trying to have a peaceful negotiation with such elements ends up essentially appeasing them, and appeasing people who are wicked only empowers them to do far worse things in the future.

So appeasement will not work with extremist elements, and the need for confrontational approaches to weed out such elements has to be acknowledged. This, in fact, is the purpose of Kshatriyas, the Bhagavad Gita says that when such approaches are required, the warrior class of people, the martial guardians of society, do not flinch from violence (18.43).

While confrontation is required for those who are power-hungry, violence can never bring lasting peace.

After the extremist elements have been purged, the non-confrontational approaches can also help us to come towards some level of peace, and this is where the Bhagwat Gita's wisdom offers humanity in general and seekers in particular resources for raising human consciousness.

The Gita informs that human nature usually falls into three categories-  or three modes- sattva, rajas, and tamas. 

The mode of tamas is associated with complaining, violence, and destruction. The mode of rajas symbolizes craving and fighting or doing whatever is required to fulfill the craving. And the mode of sattva is associated with clarifying, with trying to understand the situation.

If while pursuing violent means to curve extremists, simultaneously non-confrontational methods are pursued to eventually establish a more workable peace, then that is the way to go beyond such horrifying confrontations that are happening today?

Children are paying the highest price for a conflict they have no part in.

Everything possible must be done to protect children in both the Occupied Palestinian Territory and Israel from harm, and provide them they support they need.

We dedicate ourselves to action for good. To use our skills in support of the health, safety, and wellness of impacted communities throughout Israel, for as long as this conflict ensues. To foster a community of compassion, creativity, and unwavering commitment. Join us and help design a better future for all.

Click the link in our bio to learn more and support.

McDonald's Pakistan announced a substantial donation of PKR 10 million to support Gaza victims through the renowned Edhi Foundation.

This philanthropic endeavor comes in the midst of ongoing controversy surrounding McDonald's worldwide due to its indirect provision of free meals to the Israeli occupation army.

In a statement released on its official page, McDonald's Pakistan clarified its position, asserting that it is a locally run company with no affiliations to McDonald's Israel.

It further highlighted the company's commitment to addressing the pressing humanitarian crisis in Gaza, emphasising its dedication to offering assistance to those affected by the protracted conflict in the region.

"The WP supports Singapore‚Äôs long-held position that a two-state solution consistent with UN Security Council (UNSC) resolutions is the only viable path to a durable, just and comprehensive resolution to the long-standing conflict between Israel and Palestine

In particular, UNSC Resolution 242 which is supported by Singapore, calls for the withdrawal of Israel from Palestinian territories occupied since the 1967 war in exchange for a lasting peace with its neighbours.

Worryingly, the continuing conflict in Israel and Palestine is likely to increase attacks against Jews and Muslims elsewhere, raising the prospect of radicalisation far beyond the Middle-East, making the world more unsafe and dangerous for all countries, particularly where multi-racial and multi-cultural communities live in peace and harmony. All Singaporeans should be aware and mindful of this possibility, and play an active part to prevent it from happening on our shores." - @wpsgp

Attackers threw two Molotov cocktails at a synagogue and a Jewish community center in Berlin overnight, police said on Wednesday.

Following the attack, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed that the government would fight antisemitism in Germany.

The attack comes as a conflict rages between Israel and the Islamist militant group Hamas, which Germany, the EU and several other countries classify as a terrorist organization.

Berlin police said they were probing the attack in the city's Mitte district. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

The attack occurred around 3:45 a.m. local time (0145 GMT).

"Two unidentified people came on foot and threw two burning bottles filled with liquid in the direction of the synagogue on Brunnenstrasse," police said in a statement.

"The bottles landed on the pavement and broke, extinguishing the fire."

Berlin's Jewish Community called for solidarity with the targeted synagogue.

"85 years after Kristallnacht, synagogues in Germany's capital are set to burn again," said community chair Gideon Joffe, referring to mass looting and arson of Jewish businesses and institutions under Nazi Germany.

"The anti-Jewish violence on the streets of Berlin has thus taken on a new dimension."

(I‚Äôve gotten some pushback from a handful people for daring to post stories that use the term ‚Äúgenocide.‚Äù So‚Ä¶. In addition to directly LISTENING to and BELIEVING the people who are being directly impacted, if 800 international scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies  that include prominent Holocaust and genocide scholars are sounding the alarm and HAVE been for some time, that the crime of genocide is being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip in a public statement to the global community then what more evidence do you need?) 

Please call your representatives to call for an immediate ceasefire, to send humanitarian aid and assistance to Gaza and save as many lives as possible (resources linked in my stories), show up to protests, and continue to bear witness however much you want to look away. 

May our global grief and rage and horror and heartbreak alchemize into tangible community action and collective liberation, over and over and over, for the rest of our lives.

In his own words, Guterres stated, "I call for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire to... ease the epic human suffering we are witnessing," during a forum of the Belt and Road infrastructure project underway in Beijing.

Sweet, sensitive and full of life that‚Äôs exactly how we‚Äôd describe Jem. This beautiful boy is a kind and gentle soul. He‚Äôs looking for friends not conflict and would much rather focus on the non-stressful things in life. Lovers like Jem need equally gentle adopters. Those willing to ease him in to new experiences and make life a series of positive outcomes. We love the gentle souls. They can be easy to train because they‚Äôre so willing to please and want nothing more than a kind word and a soft touch. 

Jem almost didn‚Äôt get to experience all the good  this world has to offer. He was euthanasia listed when he came down with an upper respiratory infection at our county shelter. Already shy and unassuming in the shelter environment. He didn‚Äôt stand out and then a super infectious illness risked his life. He needed time and that‚Äôs exactly what we could give him. Jem headed to our rescue ranch where he has quickly recovered into the wonderful boy we all know and love. 

Jem‚Äôs kindness has followed him into rescue life. He‚Äôs super duper submissive to every dog and human he‚Äôs met. He‚Äôs a total lover not a fighter. He‚Äôs completely cat friendly with no prey drive cause he just wants to be everyone‚Äôs best friend. He still has a puppy like personality and is a blank skate. Ranch staff are working on the basics of good dog manners and he‚Äôs picking everything up quickly. His beautiful blue eyes are soft and gentle and we‚Äôre pretty sure they‚Äôll pull you in and make you fall in love. We know we have. If you love the gentle souls who are beautiful both inside and out then Jem just might be the pup for you.

Applications for permits to hold assemblies in relation to the Israel - Palestine conflict will be turned down due to public safety and security concerns.

"The Police are aware of events and public assemblies being organised in relation to the Israel-Hamas conflict. The National Parks Board (NParks) has also received applications to use the Speakers‚Äô Corner for events related to the Israel-Hamas conflict.

The Police have assessed that there are public safety and security concerns associated with such events, given the heightened tensions. NParks shares the same concerns. There have been numerous incidents of violence reported in many countries amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict. For instance, an Israeli staff from the Israeli Embassy in Beijing was stabbed in front of a supermarket, and a teacher was fatally stabbed by a Chechen individual in France. "The Gallucci Gallery" by K. B. Richards is an enthralling and psychologically intricate thriller that takes readers on a suspenseful journey through the complexities of Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) and the dark mysteries surrounding the Gallucci family.

The novel's protagonist, Bianca Gallucci, faces an extraordinary and daunting challenge as she grapples with DID, a condition characterized by the presence of multiple distinct personalities within a single individual. This aspect of her character adds a unique and compelling layer to the story. Her initial life of relative contentment takes a chilling turn when a mysterious man named Pascal intrudes, leaving a cryptic gift at her gallery.

The plot unfolds with a gripping mix of elements‚Äîmystery, suspense, and psychological drama. The central conflict, involving the kidnapping of Bianca's children and a demand to return a stolen painting, keeps readers on the edge of their seats. As Bianca's other personality surfaces, it triggers a riveting exploration of her psychological struggle and the complex dynamics at play within her mind.

One of the story's strengths is the deep sense of urgency and emotional intensity it conveys. As Bianca is compelled to comply with Pascal's demands and face the prospect of murder, the narrative delves into a web of lies and deceit. This journey of self-discovery and the unraveling of dark family secrets makes for a compelling and thought-provoking read.

The book's title, "The Gallucci Gallery," sets the stage for an art-themed thriller that ultimately reveals itself as a gripping psychological thriller. The novel effectively blurs the lines between reality and the fractured perceptions of the main character, leading readers to question which personality may be responsible for the alleged murder and the web of deception.

 "The Gallucci Gallery" is a unique and exhilarating rollercoaster of a novel. It challenges the reader to explore the depths of human psychology, deception, and the pursuit of justice. K. B. Richards skillfully crafts a suspenseful and thought-provoking narrative that keeps the audience engaged throughout the journey. This book is a must-read book.

"The Virus of Beauty: Wilf Gilvary Series - Book 1" by C. B. Lyall is a compelling young adult fantasy novel that seamlessly combines elements of magic, mystery, and adventure to create a captivating and thought-provoking story.

The book introduces readers to a world where beauty holds power, but that power becomes a source of panic as the Virus of Beauty spreads throughout the witch population in the Magical Realm. The story primarily follows Wilf Gilvary, a teenage wizard who, despite his magical abilities, is terrified of using magic. This fear forms a central part of his character and sets the stage for his character development throughout the book.

The mysterious death of Wilf's father propels him into a complex and dangerous political struggle between witches and wizards. The plot masterfully blends the personal journey of a young boy grieving the loss of his father with the larger themes of power, magic, and responsibility. Readers will find themselves empathizing with Wilf's desire for a normal life, making his character relatable and endearing.

One of the book's strengths lies in its exploration of fear and courage. Wilf's internal conflict regarding his fear of magic and the need to use it to save his friend Katryna is both a relatable and inspiring aspect of the story. It emphasizes the theme that true courage is not the absence of fear but the ability to confront it, making it a valuable lesson for young adult readers.

The narrative is well-paced, keeping readers engaged as Wilf races against time to unlock the secrets of his father's journal and find a cure for the Virus of Beauty. The book's title is intriguing and directly relates to the central conflict in the story, drawing readers in with its unique concept.

"The Virus of Beauty" is a strong start to the Wilf Gilvary Series. It offers a rich blend of magic, mystery, and personal growth, making it an excellent choice for young adult readers who enjoy stories of courage and adventure. C. B. Lyall's writing is not only engaging but also thought-provoking, and it sets the stage for an exciting series that promises to explore even more complex themes in future installments.

Guest post

AOM

I remember very clearly when I was only seven that I wished for a superpower so I could free the people of occupied Kashmir. A dream to work for the UN was born. I later realised how powerless the UN was when it came to ending the genocides and wars especially in the Middle East. 

I realised how racism was so prevalent in the security council and the only voice that mattered was the voice of few. 

In 2003 when the UK invaded Iraq I was heartbroken. I spent days crying. And each time any other war happened, I would become distressed. 

Now with the onslaught on Gaza. I've felt nothing but deep sickness in the pit of my stomach. I'm not functioning well at all. The images on the media are harrowing and fill me with anxiety and feelings of hopelessness.

When events are as disturbing as this plays out on our screens, it can harm the mental well-being of thousands, especially those with pre-existing health issues, such as PTSD, Eating Disorders. 

As long as I live I am never going to forget how each and every single war made me feel. How it impacted my mental health.

I question so often what did people of Afghanistan did so wrong that they have been subject of indiscriminate bombing forever. 

Don't people of Kashmir have right to freedom.

Why Palestinians have suffered forever and why flag bearers of human rights cannot stop this ongoing genocide?

Yemen, Sudan, Iraq, Lebanon, Syria, Libya. The list is endless.

Am I on a brink of relapse? Why am I remembering all the previous wars? Why eating has become so difficult and why I feel so guilty of eating and living in a country that is somehow responsible for the plight of the people of Kashmir and Palestine.

The toll on Gaza is immeasurable, and with each passing day, the pain and suffering intensify. We cannot stand idly by as our brothers and sisters in Palestine endure this harrowing crisis. Our moral duty is clear: to offer our heartfelt prayers and extend a compassionate hand in their time of desperate need.

#eatingdisorders
#palestine #trauma #conflict #ptsd #eatingdisordersupport #eatingdisordersmuslims

If we want resilient kids, we‚Äôve got to give them the opportunities to flex their resilience muscles and develop their resilience skills. Too often, we‚Äôre doing the opposite, always looking over their shoulders, never giving them the freedom to dabble, explore, mess up, find their path, connect with likeminded others, and see that the world isn‚Äôt a dangerous place.

While many adults lament kids retreating into video games, we think it offers one of the clearest examples of the problem. Video games are this generation‚Äôs sandlot. It‚Äôs a place free of adults, where kids can mess up, talk trash, lose, and bounce back‚Äîall without an adult hovering over them. Adults have forced kids into the video game box. It‚Äôs the one area where adults can‚Äôt get in the way.

It‚Äôs time to reverse course. Our kids desperately need it. We need to give kids the space to explore, mess up, and maybe even break a bone or two. Adults need to realize that the price of a broken wrist at age six is much less than the cost of a young adult who hasn‚Äôt learned the skills to manage their emotions or explore the world around them. Yet adults only see the broken wrist, not the much greater, albeit hidden, cost of safetyism.

Decades of ‚Äãresearch shows‚Äã that when we turn up the dial on threats, whether perceived or real, our brains listen. We‚Äôre more likely to avoid conflict instead of approach it, react instead of respond, and isolate instead of connect.

Without being aware of it, adults are training kids to have hypersensitive threat alarms, without the tools or resources to handle any sort of challenge. The consequences are dire. 

We wrote a full article going in depth on the research and what we can do about it the micromanaging of kids. Check it out: Link in bio.

Note: For clarities sakes, while the cited study is about playing in neighborhoods, other research shows there‚Äôs a decline in playing outside: be it in yards, parks, etc. A meta-analysis on kids independent play found 5 factors:
1. Parental restrictions (safety concerns)
2. Societal changes (organization of all, community)
3. Environment
4. Policy issues (kids not having a voice)
5. Child characteristics

What happened: UK PM Rishi Sunak announces 10 million pounds aid for Palestinians, calls them 'victims of Hamas‚Äô. In his address, Sunak strongly condemned Hamas' actions and referred to their attacks on Israel as a "pogrom," a term denoting an organized massacre based on ethnicity or religion. He also claimed that Hamas was using innocent Palestinians as human shields. Talks are underway between UK officials and other countries, including Israel and Egypt, to open the Rafah crossing in Gaza for humanitarian aid. Importantly, the UK government clarified that none of the aid funding goes to Hamas and undergoes rigorous oversight.

Details: The death toll from the Israel-Hamas conflict has tragically surpassed 4,000 people, with Hamas' attacks on Israel resulting in approximately 1,300 civilian casualties, including children, and the loss of 291 Israeli soldiers' lives. Additionally, Hamas fighters have taken Israeli citizens as hostages.

More: In Gaza, the toll is equally devastating, with over 2,750 people, including more than 700 children, losing their lives. Nearly 10,000 individuals have been wounded, and an alarming 10,000 people remain missing, as reported by authorities. The Opposition Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, emphasized the severity of the humanitarian crisis and called for Israel's defense to align with international law while expressing unity in the UK's stance during this crisis.

Are you having the same fight with your partner over and over again?

Here‚Äôs what research from The Gottman Institute shows us on conflict:

70% of relationship problems are not solvable üëÄ

üîÖ Solvable problems: these are situational and involve things like, cleaning, managing kids or in-laws, travel, etc. There isn't a deep or underlying meaning, and usually a solution.

üîÖ Perpetual problems: these are based on differences in your needs and personalities. These tend to be recurring among couples.

üîÖ Gridlocked perpetual problems: these may have been mishandled in the past because they are distressing. Many times, there are deeper issues underlying them that are not openly discussed.

If you‚Äôre stuck in a negative cycle of one of these types of problems, it can feel so painful and really hold you back from growing in your relationship. 

When I work with individuals or couples, I try to help them understand if any of their core needs are associated with the problems they are presenting with. It makes a big difference in how we address them and come up with ways to move forward.

Send me a message if you‚Äôre ready to break your unhealthy patterns and work together to improve ‚ô•Ô∏è

üì∏: ‚Äã"Hamas on Monday released its first video showing footage of a hostage the terrorist group took in its raid on Israel 10 days ago.

The video shows a 21-year-old Israeli-French woman kidnapped from the Supernova Music Festival, where the brutal militants also killed some 260 revelers.

Israeli news has identified the hostage as Mia Shem from Shoham, Israel.

In the roughly minute-long clip shared on X, formerly known as Twitter, Shem is initially seen getting her arm, which appears to have a row of stitches on it, bandaged, before she directly addresses the camera.

'Everything is fine,' she says, in part. 'I ask that they bring me home as soon as possible.'"

His 32-year-old mother also suffered more than a dozen stab wounds, the sheriff‚Äôs office said.

Something that can offer some peace + inner relief in times as heavy as right now is this... that there‚Äôs simply things we can‚Äôt accept and that accepting we can‚Äôt accept something is actually a huge part of acceptance. A way to create a safe container to meet our self again without resistance. To allow ourselves to be exactly what we are which helps us return to unity & Oneness within.‚Ä®‚Ä®So what is acceptance? To me it‚Äôs being seen. It‚Äôs holding space for something. Allowance. Allowing it to exist instead of denying it. ‚Ä®‚Ä®Now let‚Äôs go back to our paths, our life lessons, our thought-forms and our emotions... there‚Äôs simply moments on our journey and things that occur within the collective that are simply too heavy, too traumatic, and full of too much density for us to always understand. There‚Äôs things we could have never imagined happening that do. Ways people treat us especially when we were a child that we can‚Äôt make sense of. Wars. Loss. And I‚Äôve been seeing in clients and collectively right now in these powerful times of change that by forcing ourselves to try and be ok with something that really isn‚Äôt ok with us is a form of force. It‚Äôs conflict. It‚Äôs an inner war. It‚Äôs going against our truth. And then the fact that we‚Äôre trying to see something from a higher perspective, but we can‚Äôt, can cause even more lack of safety, making us feel like something further is wrong with us, more inner conflict, and a lack of feeling seen or supported which creates more dysregulation. 

So I just wanted to remind you that it‚Äôs more than ok to accept that you can‚Äôt accept something. Sometimes it‚Äôs actually the healthiest choice for yourself, the one full of the most love, when you‚Äôre up against something that‚Äôs just too big and overwhelming on the other side of you. So surrender to that. Just allow some things to be unacceptable if they truly feel that way. This will help to actually bring you into harmony vs. resistance. It will restore your peace & ease some of your fear. ‚Ä®‚Ä®If you‚Äôre interested in identifying your subconscious patterns, regulating your nervous system, clearing away outdated energetic patterns & reframing your life experiences, 1-on-1 sessions are open ‚ú®

Popular Bollywood actress Sonam Kapoor is the latest celebrity to break the silence on the ongoing war between Hamas and Israel. The war has claimed thousands of innocent lives to date but tension escalated after Hamas launched an unprecedented strike on Israel this month. Various celebrities across the globe have reacted to the conflict but Sonam Kapoor is the only Bollywood actress after Swara Bhasker who spoke on the issue. Taking to her Instagram story, she said that half of the people in Gaza are children. She also shared an excerpt from the New York Time op-ed which is written by eminent columnist Nicholas Kristof. Tennis star Sania Mirza too shared the same post on her Instagram.

SEEKING THE ULTIMATE TRUTH ‚ù§Ô∏èüñ§üíö

Self-knowledge is actual knowledge‚Äîall other knowledge changes. What we learn in school differs based on the period of time. Our school knowledge is not based on what's good for us but rather on the best way to govern and control others.

That's why some communities send their children to two schools‚Äîone to learn about others, the other to learn about themselves. So, with all that we think we know, such as the name of the first president, sadly, we don't know who we are. We've spent years believing in the intellect and not the spirit. As a result, we stay childlike, superficially smart, and uninvolved instead of wise and evolved.

With self-knowledge, we become empowered with thoughts that transcend this world. We seek that ultimate truth. But to seek that truth, we must realize the conflict within ourselves.

That conflict is to either remain asleep or wake up. As the story goes, we can be like "Iai," an ass that won't let go of the lies or falsehood. Undoubtedly, we've become stubborn in thinking that the path is one of assimilation with a dominant force, whereas it's one of assimilating with a life force. No one will empower you with self-knowledge, which leads us to the "ultimate" truth. Give yourself the gift of waking up to truly being free. -Dr. Robbin Alston

Iran on Wednesday urged members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) to take a strong stance against Israel following the deadly strike on al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza, claiming more than 500 lives.

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian called for the imposition of an oil embargo and other sanctions on Israel and the expulsion of all Israeli ambassadors. He made these remarks during an emergency OIC meeting in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, which aimed to address the escalating Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

According to an official statement, the Iranian FM "calls for an immediate and complete embargo on Israel by Islamic countries, including oil sanctions, in addition to expelling Israeli ambassadors if relations with the Zionist regime have been established‚Äù.

Amirabdollahian also proposed the creation of a team of Islamic lawyers to document potential war crimes committed by Israel in Gaza. It's important to note that Iran has no diplomatic relations with Israel.

The call for action came after a devastating Israeli air raid on a hospital in Gaza, resulting in a high casualty count, according to Palestinians. Gaza‚Äôs Health Ministry spokesperson, Ashraf al-Qudra, reported that hundreds of people lost their lives, and rescue efforts were still underway to recover bodies from the rubble.

Posting about breastfeeding, as passionate as I am about it, feels trivial this morning as thousands of innocent people are being massacred every in what is becoming a daily occurrence. 

I do not have all or even many of the answers, but I do know that if we do not learn from history, it will repeat itself over & over.

The humanitarian crises in the Middle East right now is devastating & my heart breaks for the innocent mothers, children, fathers & families whose worlds are being destroyed by this conflict. I think what is most devastating is reading about how the current bout of violence is the latest bloody installment on a war that has been raging for decades. Can you even imagine how many lives have been lost since the beginning of this conflict?

My prayers go to every mother & father & son & daughter who are mourning. Please petition our leaders to do everything within their power to find a way forward which preserves the magic and wonder of human life üôèüèΩ

The escalating violence in Israel and Gaza has no clear end in sight and reverberates around the world, including on our campus. I have condemned the Hamas terrorist attacks that set these tragic events in motion. We mourn the loss of innocent lives across the region.
 
I am also responsible for ensuring the safety and security of our entire community while also safeguarding our ability to carry out our academic mission. 
 
This week‚Äôs campus demonstrations come at a time when many members of our community are fearful and experiencing tremendous pain. Peaceful protest ‚Äì and all that comes with it‚Äîis a feature of campus life. As a university, we support free expression, along with a commitment to the safety and security of our community and the values we share and work to advance. The deeply held and disparate views of the Israel-Palestinian conflict often put these sacred values in tension, and this crisis is testing and will test our community in many ways. 
 
Penn will not tolerate and will take immediate action against any incitement to violence or, of course, actual violence. We are monitoring upcoming events closely through Penn Public Safety and are exercising extreme vigilance to prevent violence on our campus. If there is an immediate threat to your physical safety, call our 24/7 PennComm Emergency Call Center: 215-573-3333 
 
We are all members of the Penn community, and we all deserve to be heard and respected. But hateful speech has no place at Penn. No place. I categorically condemn hateful speech that denigrates others as contrary to our values. In this tragic moment, we must respect the pain of our classmates and colleagues and recognize that our speech and actions have the power to both harm and heal our community. We must choose healing, resisting those who would divide us and instead respect and care for one another.
 
There are more difficult days ahead, with more casualties and loss to come in this war. Please be kind to yourselves, approach each other from a place of compassion and understanding, and seek support when you need it. The Penn community is here for you. 
 
For the full text of my message, please visit the link in my bio.

Mideast conflict: Growing death toll

4,200 dead in 10 days.

The death toll in the latest and bloodiest episode in the Middle East conflict continues to rise.

The tally includes a large number of women and children, with many more bodies yet to be found from the rubble.

The ongoing battle sparked by the Hamas cross-border attack on Oct. 7 prompted a brutal response from a shaken Israeli nation.

The results are casualties on both sides and civilians caught in the crossfire.

The last blast that killed 500 in a Gaza hospital raises further the death toll, and the ending to this conflict is still nowhere in the horizon for now.

The tragic humanitarian crisis continues to unfold before our eyes for the civilian population in Gaza, this time with mass casualties of innocent civilians at a hospital. 

Reports estimate upwards of 500 dead at present.

Responsibility is being contested by all parties, with both sides pointing the finger at each other. 

One should be clear though that those responsible need to be held accountable to the full extent of international law regardless of who they are. 

This is also leading to even more increased international tensions as the Arab world reacts to the devastating scenes. Some reports also show people in the surrounding region taking to the street in protest and attempting to storm Israeli embassies. 

Realtime coverage of these events may also be distressing to people, especially as coverage in legacy outlets are rapidly changing over a short period of time.

Truth is often the first casualty of war and right now many of us obversering are getting fed intense propaganda from supporters of all sides in this conflict, with a lot of analysis of things that are impossible to discern instantly from online videos or images.

As the fighting intensifies and the horrors for civilian populations increase, the information war has become more calculated with deliberately crafted language and imagery aimed at winning the hearts and minds of the international community.

The legacy media, unless they can 100% verify, need to word their headlines carefully if they don't have boots on the ground or did not witness an incident firsthand.

It's also disconcerting to see multiple people I follow, who usually exhibit more discernment, sharing doctored or outdated videos and images not once, but consistently.

I can't say for certain if it's intentional or unintentional, but it's certainly concerning.

Angels of ignorance / 2018
This work was created in 2018 and does not refer to any conflict. It is a tribute to all the innocent victims of wars.

#martinakis #nowar #stopwar #peace #save #innocent

An Israeli air raid on the Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza reportedly claimed the lives of more than 500 Palestinians ‚Äì including displaced individuals seeking shelter, hospital staff, and patients, both young and old, Al Jazeera reported. The news ‚Äì and graphic photographs and videos emerging from the site of the bombing ‚Äì was accompanied by calls for trigger warnings. But as one user on X pointed out, ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre triggered by hearing people talk about it then imagine how the Palestinians are feeling as they live through it‚Ä¶ [They] don‚Äôt get trigger warnings seeing their innocent families and friends getting murdered‚Ä¶ [If] they don‚Äôt get a trigger warning, you don‚Äôt either.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
What started as a well-intentioned tool to avoid unintentionally triggering people‚Äôs trauma has now been relegated to instruments of virtue-signalling rooted in privilege. Many have criticised people on social media demanding trigger warnings on news and think-pieces focusing on the crisis in Gaza, pointing out how it speaks to their privilege. The argument of ‚Äòchoosing' ‚Äì while distanced from the conflict itself ‚Äì whether or not to engage with evidence of violence no longer seems to hold as strongly. If content depicting the first-hand distress of people in the eye of the violence causes second-hand distress -- it‚Äôs causing precisely the reaction it should. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Yes, the digital age necessitates a culture of consent ‚Äì but not to the extent that it allows people to overlook mass violence. Amid the persistent demand for trigger warnings even now, what‚Äôs been overlooked all along is researchers being heavily conflicted on the efficacy of using trigger warnings. Tap the link in bio to read @devruparakshit‚Äôs piece from the archives on why we‚Äôre insistent on holding on to trigger warnings despite research suggesting they‚Äôre counterproductive.

Note: This blurb has been updated to cite the Al Jazeera report on the air raid.

The loss of children in Palestine during times of war is an indescribable tragedy that words fail to encompass. The heartache and devastation that families endure is beyond measure, shattering dreams and tearing at the very fabric of their existence.

In the midst of conflict, children in Palestine face unimaginable hardships. They are innocent souls caught in the crossfire, facing dangers that no child should ever have to encounter. Fear, violence, and uncertainty become their daily reality, robbing them of the carefree joys of childhood.

The loss of a child during war is a wound that never truly heals. It leaves families shattered and communities grieving, forever altered by the absence of these precious young lives. The pain is etched deeply in the hearts of parents, eternally mourning the loss of their beloved children.

Compassion and empathy are crucial when addressing the impact of child loss in Palestine. It is a profound sorrow that resonates across borders, transcending political divides. The loss of these young lives echoes not only within their families but also within the collective consciousness of humanity.
In the face of such immense tragedy, it is essential to extend support, understanding, and compassion to the affected families. Offering empathy to the grieving parents and communities creates a space where healing can slowly begin. Recognizing their pain and acknowledging the depth of their suffering is an act of compassion that can provide some semblance of comfort in the midst of profound grief.

Beyond offering condolences, it is crucial to work towards a peaceful resolution, one that protects the lives of children and fosters a future where they can flourish free from the horrors of war. By advocating for peace, we can strive to prevent further loss and ensure that every child in Palestine can grow up in a world where their potential is nurtured, dreams are realized, and their lives are valued above all else.

In the face of such unimaginable devastation, solidarity, compassion, and a commitment to peace are the pillars that can provide hope in the darkest of times.

Rest in peace little one

This is the face of who is actually getting harmed in the current (and long long ongoing) Hamas- Israeli Conflict

Rahaf was ten

The coverage is confusing. And the fear for someone like me is getting it wrong in a response. There is a lot I have no idea about

Two sides. Politics coming into play. Entrenched and complicated. I have friends who identify across all levels of these conflicts. Difficult to understand. I have heard a lot of arguments about history. 

Of course history matters. 

But how much does it matter when these are the victims: Children who should be playing and being loved. I bet they knew little about the nuances. 

They should be being kept safe by INTERNATIONALLY protected agreements. You shouldn‚Äôt know who this child is because she should be quietly thriving in childhood. 

But she is dead

It doesn‚Äôt matter which group she came from. Every child has this same right. Your child, my child, every child.

An eye for an eye. Steeped in raw and deep history, religion, desperation. Generational loss, oppression. And yet it continues. It can be confusing to look in on. I even struggle with the terminology. I know there is so much I don‚Äôt know. 

But I do know this. These are people caught up. Innocent lives. Versions of you and me who have nowhere to turn. Who just want to live their lives. Do their jobs. Be with their families. 

The terrorist actions of Hammas are deplorable. But the Israeli response too is. There is dark and terrible happenings on both sides. And the innocent victims are aplenty. 

I have been sent footage of doctors just like me, showing that they are now unable to protect and treat. Hospitals and healthcare staff should always be safe haven. 

We must pressure our own governments to call for immediate ceasefire. To halt these atrocities. International law tells us we shouldn‚Äôt stand for any of this. Basic human rights tell us we shouldn‚Äôt stand for any of this. Bring a normal person tells us we shouldn‚Äôt stand for this.

Write to your MPs today and tell them they need to place international pressure for an immediate ceasefire. You don‚Äôt need to understand every complexity. Protect the children.

Did you know that time spent on workplace conflict has doubled since 2008? That‚Äôs according to the most recent Conflict at Work research released by The Myers-Briggs Company. As it turns out, poor communication is the number one cause of conflict. Conflict is a healthy part of relating to other people. But it can be tricky at work‚Äîespecially if you disagree with your boss.

Maybe your manager announces his next great idea, and you think it‚Äôs destined for failure. Or you may have received a performance review rating that you vehemently disagree with. Whatever the scenario, you never want to burst into your boss‚Äô office and scream at the top of your lungs, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre absolutely wrong!‚Äù Instead, consider whether you want to confront your boss or keep quiet. A key reason to openly disagree with your manager is when it benefits the overall organization. If you can show your boss that you have the company's best interests in mind, a difference of opinion can be a win-win for both of you.

Brian, a six-year-old male Indian rhino from Ohio's @columbuszoo, has made his public debut in the Asian Highlands. 

Currently, guests can spot him in the Indian rhino yard nearest to the takin habitat. Once he's fully acclimated to his new home, he will be paired with Hellary, the Zoo's 15-year-old female Indian rhino.

With only about 4,000 of these rhinos remaining in India and Nepal, Brian's arrival marks an exciting step forward in the Zoo's ongoing rhino conservation efforts.

‚ÄúHuman population growth within the Indian rhino‚Äôs home range has led to a decrease in habitat and increase in human-animal conflict," said Ryan Sears, our curator of large mammals. 

"Despite these challenges, the recovery of the population for this species has been a conservation success in recent years, due to the changes made in management practices and protective measures. We are excited to continue to tell this conservation story with Brian.

International Law Supports Palestinian Right to Resistance:

In the face of ongoing global debate regarding the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, it is crucial to understand the legal context surrounding the Palestinian people's right to resist occupying forces. While organisations such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad are designated as proscribed groups in numerous Western nations, it is essential to recognize that many other factions choose to exercise their legal right to resist occupation. This legal right is well-established within the framework of international law.

Israel's occupation of Palestinian territory is a topic of significant concern, with its legitimacy disputed by many. According to the United Nations (UN) and the Geneva Conventions, people living under occupation have a recognized and legitimate right to resist. This right is grounded in numerous international resolutions that affirm the principles of national liberation and self-determination, even including armed struggle.

As stated in UN General Assembly resolutions, "Dozens of resolutions by the UNGA support national liberation movements in their struggle for independence and self-determination, including armed struggle, as exemplified by Resolution 2105 of 1965."

Furthermore, international humanitarian law explicitly acknowledges the right to engage in wars of national liberation as a protected and essential right for occupied populations, as outlined in Additional Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions of 1949.

For a comprehensive understanding of the legal basis for the Palestinian right to resistance, you can refer to the following sources:

1. UN General Assembly Resolutions: law4palestine.org/do-palestinians-have-the-right-to-resist-and-what-are-the-limits-short-article/

2. International Humanitarian Law Documentation: treaties.un.org/doc/publication/unts/volume%201125/volume-1125-i-17512-english.pdf

In light of these legal frameworks, it is evident that the Palestinian people possess a recognized right to resist occupation, supported by international law and United Nations resolutions. This right remains an essential aspect of their pursuit of self-determination and national liberation.

HISTORY OF THE ROMAN-TARENTINE WARS
‚ûñ
Tarentum was a Greek city located in southern Italy which was founded in the 8th century BC by Spartan colonists, one of many similar cities founded across the Mediterranean. Over time it was able to grow into a prosperous and influential community, with Greeks and Greek culture becoming widespread in southern Italy, enough for the region to be called "Magna Graecia". Tarentum also developed a strong army, including a talented cavalry force, and with this was able to enforce its influence in the region, becoming a pre-eminent power.
---
Although Rome likely knew of Tarentum beforehand, their first serious diplomatic contacts appear to have come in the 290s BC after Rome's victory in the Third Samnite War, after which they founded several new colonies in Apulia and Lucania, much to the worry of Tarentum. Worse still was the fact that Rome was quickly growing her influence in Magna Graecia and overtaking Tarentine power. Matters reached a breaking point in 283 BC when the Tarentines, in a fit of panic, attacked a Roman fleet carrying soldiers to Thurii that came close to their city due to being blown off course by bad weather.
---
Rome was surprised by this move and tried to negotiate with Tarentum, but the Greeks instead mocked their ambassadors, leading to the Romans and Tarentum going to full war. The conflict proved very one sided as the overconfident Tarentines were defeated in battle, and by 281 BC were torn over negotiating for peace. The city seemed to get a much needed reprieve when the Greek king Pyrrhus of Epirus answered their call for aid and arrived in Italy with an army. The Tarentines fought alongside the Epirotes against Rome in the Pyrrhic War (280-275 BC), but despite their contribution Pyrrhus was eventually defeated. The Romans returned in 272 BC, and this time conquered Tarentum for good, defeating the last bastion of resistance to their rule in Magna Graecia.
---
#Rome #Roma #RomanArmy #RomanLegion #RomanRepublic #SPQR #Tarentum #Taranto #MagnaGraecia #History #RomanHistory #GreekHistory #AncientHistory #MilitaryHistory

MMU condemns attack on Gaza hospital that killed over 500

Srinagar, Oct 18: Muttahida Majlis-e-Ulema (MMU), the largest amalgam of religious, social and educational organisations of Jammu and Kashmir led by Mirwaiz Umar Farooq has condemned the attack on Gaza hospital that killed over 500 people on Tuesday. 

In a joint statement, issued MMU expressed shock and outrage and said the people of J&K are deeply saddened and pained by this unfolding tragedy and stand in solidarity with the people of Palestine.

The statement reads that it is a blatant war crime under United Nations Charter and the Geneva Conventions, and the people of Palestine are being collectively punished by Israel and all their human rights have been snatched from them.

MMU urged the UN and world powers to move beyond blame game and partisanship, and see what is happening in Gaza for what it is humanitarian crisis.

It urged them to ensure that the war against hapless Palestinian citizens is stopped and a resolution to this long term conflict is immediately sought.

It also urged the muslim countries to unite and stand with the Palestinian people and ensure they get justice.

The MMU consists of other members including Mufti Azam‚Äôs Muslim Personal Law Boards, Anjuman Auqaf Jama Masjid, Jamiat Ahle Hadees, Anjuman Sharie Shian, Darul Uloom Raheemiya Karwaan-e-Islami, Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen, Anjuman-Nusratul-Islam, Anjuman Tabligh-e-Islam, Jamiat Hamdaniyyah, Anjuman Ulema-e-Ahnaf, Darul Uloom Qasmiya, Darul Uloom Bilaliya, Anjuman Mazharul Haq, Jamiat-ul-Aima Wal Ulema, Anjuman Aima Wa Mashaaikh Kashmir, Darul Uloom Naqshbandiyya, Darul Uloom Rasheediyyah, Ahle Bayt Foundation, Madrasah Kanz-ul-Uloom, Peerwaan-e-Wilayat, Auqaf Islamia Khurram Sirhama, Bazm-e-Tawheed Ahle Hadeeth Trust, Anjuman Tanzeem-al-Makatib, Muhammadi Trust, Anjuman Anwar-ul-Islam, Kaarwaan-e-Khatam-e-Nabuwat, Darul Uloom Syed Al Mursaleen, Anjuman Ulema and Aima Masaajid, Falah Dareen Trust Welfare Society Islamabad, Idarah Wahdat-ul-Makaatib Jammu Kashmir, Darul Uloom Imdaadiya Natipora and other contemporary religious, social and educational associations and their rep

One positive outcome from this conflict is that many conversations will be had‚Äîbetween different groups, between different people of the same group, and even between people who didn‚Äôt know anything about the nuances of the situation before it happened. 

The worst way to start a conversation about it is by assuming that your POV is the correct, unbiased perspective and that theirs is mostly propaganda. 

That‚Äôs probably going to result in an argument or with the other person becoming unresponsive. 

Time may reveal (as it has done on many occasions before) that actually, it was the other way around. Or that each side contained a bit of truth and a bit of propaganda. 

In the meantime, let people get informed however they wish, share what they wish, and consider ALL sides. 

And when you discuss it with them, stay as open to their perspective as you would like for them to be open to yours. 

That‚Äôs how true understanding begins. 

Drop a ‚ù§Ô∏è if you are open to hearing other perspectives in order to flesh out your own.

Maybe you are not a very emotional person‚Ä¶

Maybe you consider yourself too emotional‚Ä¶

Maybe you have strong people pleasing tendencies‚Ä¶

Maybe you avoid conflict altogether‚Ä¶

Maybe you have exaggerated and intense reactions to everything‚Ä¶

Maybe you are constantly thinking ahead in worst case scenarios‚Ä¶

Maybe you have a really hard time asking others for help, relying on, or trusting others‚Ä¶

Maybe you are a ‚Äúworkaholic‚Äù‚Ä¶

Maybe you are shy or withdrawn to a level that‚Äôs impacting your life‚Ä¶

There are so many other things I could list that people often associate with their personality ‚Äî but really, it‚Äôs connected to their trauma history.

This is why it is so important to process through your past!! 

If there is a ‚Äúpersonality trait ‚Äúthat is holding you back right now‚Ä¶ I challenge you to consider working with someone from our team, to get to the root, differentiate personality from trauma, and begin to really heal and change.

President Biden announced today that the United States is providing $100 million in humanitarian assistance for the Palestinian people in Gaza and the West Bank. This funding will help support over a million displaced and conflict-affected people with clean water, food, hygiene support, medical care, and other essential needs. The United States provides humanitarian assistance through trusted partners including UN agencies and international NGOs.

Civilians are not to blame and should not suffer for Hamas‚Äôs horrific terrorism. Civilian lives must be protected and assistance must urgently reach those in need. We will continue to work closely with partners in the region to stress the importance of upholding the law of war, supporting those who are trying to get to safety or provide assistance, and facilitating access to food, water, medical care, and shelter.

We demand an immediate ceasefire.

Palestinians are on the brink of a genocide, and our government is bankrolling it. Every year, the US sends over $3 billion in military aid‚Äînow being used to rain bombs on Gaza. As Americans, we are not observers in this conflict, we are actors. That‚Äôs why we are joining calls around the world and directing them at our government to call for an immediate ceasefire, to open humanitarian aid flows into Gaza, and to end US funding for war crimes.

Over 3,300 Palestinians have been killed since last Saturday, over 1,000 of them children. One child has been killed every 15 minutes in 11 days of airstrikes. Over one million people have been displaced. There are no bomb shelters in Gaza. Hospitals have run out of painkillers, and ice cream trucks are being used to store bodies. Water is scarce.

Ceasefire is the only way for the deaths to stop. Ceasefire is the only way to bring hostages home. Ceasefire is what every person of conscience must be demanding. Ceasefire now, let in humanitarian aid, end military aid, end the blockade, end the occupation, end apartheid.

Join us on Friday at 5p, stand on the right side of history, and call for a ceasefire.

Young Maltese influencer @sarah_alfalah has used her massive social media following to condemn the "ongoing ethnic cleansing in Palestine and the apparent indifference of various ethnicities towards it".

"This feels like a load off my chest," the 23-year-old wrote on Instagram yesterday, addressing her 219,000 followers. "Use your privileged voices! Been writing and deleting this back and forth, contemplating whether to post it or not, but what the hell? Yes! I‚Äôm sharing this! This is real life! If I‚Äôm not gonna use my voice now, then when?"

"If you're at home, simply consuming news and scrolling through social media while ignoring the situation, without taking a stand, you're contributing to this tragedy. Your inaction enables the continuation of suffering."

In the series of notes shared as an Instagram carousel, Sarah not only condemned the ongoing conflict... but also made her point very clear when it came to Hamas.

"Hamas is like ISIS," she wrote. "You can't blame a nation for activists from different countries. The media will paint it that it is an activism from the country they want to destroy, like they did before with ISIS."

"Killers are in every country, you don't use a group of killers to manslaughter a nation."

"I know what it feels like to have relatives shot dead or to have your father trapped in a war that both the world and their own attacked and bombed," Alfalah confessed.

"Hearing bombs while the land line cuts. Spent two years of my life living with that fear and still going to school as a 12-year-old, privileged enough to be half-Maltese and not to experience a fraction of what he experienced in Libya."

"But those people are not privileged," Alfalah continued. "They need our privileged voices! So does Yemen and Syria, left behind from the world, uncared for."

"And If you‚Äôre selfish, remember that most countries are allies and your country might wake up tomorrow and decide to fight a war," the young influencer finished.

What do you make of Sarah's statement?

1/2 posts... It is so great we are having conversations about the mental load...
There has been so much chat about my interview the other day in which @fitzywippakate and I talked about the mental load. Unfortunately, when you get a 90sec grab from a longer conversation some of the nuance can be missed so I really wanted to just post a bit more about that here.
First of all I want to clarify that while I mention in this grab that women's tendency to worry about a whole lot of things is biological, that isn't the WHOLE story. As I have written in several of my books, gender is more fluid than fixed, and while respecting biological, neurological and hormonal differences, there is not an ‚Äòall men‚Äô or ‚Äòall women‚Äô reality.
ON TOP OF THAT, there is social conditioning that is deeply embedded in culture and ancestry. Women are socially conditioned to take care of others and be people pleasers, as I write in my book Girlhood. Just as men are conditioned to be protectors and the strong, silent types. It's not about blaming and shaming each other -- as this story on The Project illustrates well, this conditioning creates a lot of silent expectations on mums and dads, so it can cause conflict.
Hopefully having these conversations is about creating greater understanding of what might be at play here so we can then challenge it and parent together better. ... cont 1/2

Can we endure discomfort and talk about our true feelings to others, even if we know that it will make them feel unhappy? Rather than honestly addressing the situation, we often become afraid of conflict, thereby prolonging the dysfunctional circumstance by not saying anything. However, this only causes us to bottle up our feelings, which eventually erupts at the most unfortunate times, damaging the relationship much more than necessary. 

To remedy this, can we make a habit of letting people know, without aggression, how we feel whenever we notice a notable red flag in our relationship? We can‚Äôt blame them for not changing their behavior when they are unaware of how it is impacting us. So, let‚Äôs muster our courage and communicate what we see as a problem.
