Let‚Äôs talk personal growth ‚ú®

It‚Äôs crazy to think that I started this page in 2018 when I got my little white JK, and ran that thing into the ground. Little did I know this page would open my world to opportunities and allow me to meet incredible people from all over the world. 

Swipe -> to see 2018 me. A girl who was lost, working two jobs and fighting her way through college. She was overcoming trauma and closing doors to those who caused the trauma and setting firm boundaries for herself. She didn‚Äôt know it then, but she was starting a new chapter in her life. She started speaking up, and speaking out and never backed down from any conflict placed in front of her. Looking back now, I‚Äôm proud of her in more ways than one. 

Today, I stand before you after facing the greatest yet most trying year of my life. I‚Äôve learned so much in such a short amount of time about myself, about my relationships with others and about how I handle the things going on around me. 

I am 10 months in Lupus remission, and haven‚Äôt had a flare up since December of 2022. I‚Äôve been off all of the medications and I‚Äôve finally able to focus on my health for the last 10 months. With that, it‚Äôs lead me to finding my true authentic purpose in life, along with my true authentic self. 
Physical and mental health truly get put on the back burner when you‚Äôre not in a healed place in your life, and now that I am on the road to healed and can make those things a priority, life has just been.. better! 

I‚Äôve received countless DMs asking for fitness and nutrition help and I‚Äôm happy to start diving in a little deeper with you guys in regards to those things. @sashameetsfitness has truly helped me get back on track with her encouraging words and friendship! I highly recommend following her and joining her programs for a better understanding on personal health and fitness. 

As always, thank you to everyone who‚Äôs been there and who have taken the time out of their lives to give a damn about mine! I am beyond thankful for the relationships this industry has brought to me and for the opportunities I‚Äôve earned and worked so hard for. 

It‚Äôs only up from here. 

I love you guys. 

Rey

US President Biden lands in Tel¬†Aviv to meet Israeli PM Netanyahu after 500 people died in hospital strike

US President Joe Biden has arrived in Israel in a desperate bid to prevent the war with Hamas from spiralling into a wider conflict after a devastating blast on a Gaza hospital killed 500 people. 

Biden was received by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as he touched down at Ben Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv this morning amid warnings the war is 'spiralling out of control' following the deadly fireball explosion at the hospital.

A huge blast ripped through the al-Ahli Hospital in Gaza City last night while it was being used to treat and shelter thousands of civilians who were trying to avoid Israel's relentless airstrikes. 

Earlier on, President Biden was left outraged and deeply saddened" by hospital explosion in Gaza

"I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," he said. 

"Immediately upon hearing this news, I spoke with King Abdullah II of Jordan, and Prime Minister Netanyahu of Israel and have directed my national security team to continue gathering information about what exactly happened. The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."

I‚Äôve had a few messages on here over the last ten days asking where is my outrage over the events in Israel and Gaza during the past brutal ten days. 

To be honest I haven‚Äôt known how to say it or how to articulate my emotions at the horrors unfolding. 

So many well intentioned posts I‚Äôve read have ended up becoming a storm of initial disagreement and then hatred. 

Its left a lot of people, like me, not knowing what to say or how to say it, whilst feeling equally uncomfortable at remaining silent. 

It is possible and should be absolutely OK to have compassion and righteous anger about what is happening on both sides of this tragic conflict. 

It‚Äôs not about taking sides, it‚Äôs about that innate belief in the sanctity of human life. 

To cry out in anger and compassion for the unimaginable loss and pain being suffered by countless innocent families in Gaza is a perfectly human response to an inhumane situation.

To struggle to even comprehend the trauma and agony of those poor Israeli families affected by the events of October 7th and weep over the needless lives lost and kidnapped is another perfectly understandable human response to an act of unimaginable evil. 

Whatever the conflict, whatever side of the division, the loss and suffering of innocent men, women and children is always unspeakably tragic and never justified. 

As a father my heart breaks for the parents in Israel and Gaza who are suffering the unimaginable.

New Delhi: Campaigning in Mizoram for the November 7 assembly polls heated up this week with the arrival of Congress leader Rahul Gandhi for a two-day trip to the north-eastern state.

Two days in a row ‚Äì October 16 and 17 ‚Äì Gandhi not only grabbed considerable public attention in the state but also seized national headlines. His party‚Äôs state unit had been eagerly awaiting his arrival to declare the candidates‚Äô list for the assembly polls.

As planned, the party named candidates for 39 of the state‚Äôs 40 seats, leaving one seat to be decided soon.

On day one, he carried out a padyatra along the lines of his successful Bharat Jodo Yatra in Aizawl city. The four-to-five kilometre walk stretched between the Chanmari area of the capital to the Raj Bhavan.

Addressing a rally thereafter, he carried out a frontal attack on Prime Minister Narendra Modi for being more ‚Äúinterested‚Äù in addressing Israel-Hamas conflict than ‚Äúgiving importance‚Äù to Manipur. 

Stating to the public that he didn‚Äôt understand why Modi did not visit Manipur, which has been facing ethnic strife since this past May, Gandhi called it ‚Äúshameful‚Äù for the leader of the country not to visit a state after such mindless violence. 

Calling the Manipur violence a symptom of the problem with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), he stated, ‚ÄúPeople from minority communities are feeling uncomfortable and there is oppression being carried out on the people of India under its rule.‚Äù

In a simple straw shed, Sudanese refugee Zeinab seeks refuge from haunting nightmares of her husband's tragic death in Sudan.

When armed men attacked her house, they ‚Äã‚Äãshot her husband and his five brothers while Zeinab hid with her two children. Fearing for their lives as the conflict escalated, she made the dangerous journey to Chad, where she now has shelter and hopes to provide for her children's education and needs.

Conditions for Sudanese refugees like Zeinab are dire, as camps are overcrowded. Refugees live in makeshift shelters and have limited access to basic services such as water, healthcare, and food.

Despite being one of the poorest countries in the world, Chad is now hosting over 423,000 people who have fled Sudan recently. They need urgent support.

Thinking in extremes (all or nothing) feels safe especially when you don‚Äôt trust yourself or your perspective.

Problem is when there‚Äôs little room for nuance, gray areas, ambiguity, it‚Äôs extremely challenging to develop healthy, safe, sustainable relationships with others.

Every situation for you falls into one of two buckets ‚Äî good or bad. Right or wrong. All or nothing.

üò¨Which neglects context.

üëÄAvoids all conflict (even the healthy kind).

Why? Because you‚Äôre looking at them through a lens of good or bad in everything they do, say, think or feel.

This causes you to react, attack, or eliminate the relationship because there‚Äôs no room for understanding, differing opinions, alternate perspectives, growth, grace or forgiveness.

On 17th October, the 11th day of Israel's bombardments on the besieged Gaza Strip, Israel bombed the Al Ahli hospital in Gaza, killing more than 500 people including patients, doctors & those seeking refuge.

Gaza is home to 2.3 million Palestinians (1.1 million children) and is one of the world's most densely populated places. Israel has held it under siege for 17 years. In the last 11 days Israel has dropped thousands of bombs on the imprisoned population, estimated to be the equivalent force of a quarter of a nuclear bomb.
Human rights experts have also confirmed the use of the internationally-banned weapon, white phosphorus.
On 15 October 2023, over 800 scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies signed a public statement warning of the possibility of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
Signatories include prominent Holocaust and genocide studies scholars.

"As scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies, we are compelled to sound the alarm about the possibility of the crime of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. We do not do so lightly, recognising the weight of this crime, but the gravity of the current situation demands it."

At 10:30 a.m. on Oct. 18, over 80 Lowell students walked out of registry, joining a rally at the flagpole. Following speeches by rally organizers, participating students marched down Eucalyptus Drive calling for a cease-fire in the ongoing conflicts in Gaza. Speakers also called for teachers to teach about the conflict and for the U.S. to stop funding Israeli war efforts. 

The walkout, organized by Lowell‚Äôs Middle Eastern and North African Club (MENA), was just one of many occurring today across the district and the nation. ‚ÄúThis walkout is not just a single act, but a statement that our cry for freedom will never be silenced,‚Äù said junior Helena Awwad, who is the MENA co-president. 

The walkout consisted of speeches from the MENA club co-presidents, Awwad and sophomore Zayna Elkarra, whose family lives in Gaza. MENA club led a march down Eucalyptus Drive, where chants of ‚Äúfree, free Palestine‚Äù and ‚Äúsay no to genocide‚Äù filled the air. The walkout concluded with a moment of silence in Rolph Nicol Park, where the co-presidents made their final remarks.

Organizers were clear to separate the actions of the Israeli government from Israeli and Jewish people. ‚ÄúWe want to make it clear that when we are talking about Israel, we are not referring to Jewish people,‚Äù said Elkarra. ‚ÄúThe two need to be separated.‚Äù

Among the participants was Jewish student Caleb Darsky. ‚ÄúWhat motivated me to join the walkout today was seeing the amount of suffering on both sides in Israel and Palestine,‚Äù the  senior said. ‚ÄúI want to show solidarity because there‚Äôs a lot of miscommunication between Jews and Muslims, and Israelis and Palestinians. I hope that bringing my voice to this walkout can help bridge the gap.‚Äù

Organizers saw the walkout as a display of the power of student voices. ‚ÄúI absolutely believe that as youth in America, we cannot be silenced,‚Äù said Awwad. ‚ÄúThis is the time where we have to use our voices to educate people.‚Äù Elkarra echoed Awwad‚Äôs remarks: ‚ÄúI want the world to wake up, to really see and understand what‚Äôs going on.‚Äù

What happened: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that Canada will provide an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance. This funding supports life-saving efforts, including providing food, water, emergency medical assistance, and protection services. The move comes in response to the dire situation in the region due to the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

Details: The humanitarian aid will be directed toward various organizations, including the Canadian Red Cross, the Palestine Red Crescent Society, and Magen David Adom. These organizations will scale their efforts to assist people in urgent need, particularly those internally displaced in Gaza and the West Bank.

Also: The Canadian government emphasized its commitment to ensuring that no funds would end up in the hands of Hamas, a declared terrorist organization. They mentioned implementing "enhanced due diligence" and anti-terrorism exercises to safeguard against such misuse of funds.

More: The situation in Gaza has worsened, with reports of shortages of essential supplies, including water and power. The UN has raised concerns about these actions violating international humanitarian law. The International Committee of the Red Cross also called for humanitarian access to Gaza through a neutral party to provide essential aid and facilitate communication between hostages and their families.

On behalf of @petaindia , I‚Äôve called upon the Hon‚Äôble Deputy Chief Minister of Maharashtra Shri @devendra_fadnavis ji who is also the Home Minister of Maharashtra, to withdraw the relevant portion of the Government Resolution (GR) passed by the Home Department, Government of Maharashtra on 26 September imposing a ban on community animals and their feeding inside Mantralaya premises. Several dogs and cats have been peacefully coexisting inside Mantralaya premises for years together and they know no other home. The said portion of the GR is bad in law and hence must be withdrawn with immediate effect.
 
Persons who feed community animals are merely discharging their fundamental duty as envisaged under Article 51(A)(g) of the Constitution of India. Article 51(A)(g) imposes a fundamental duty on every citizen to have ‚Äúcompassion for living creatures‚Äù, which certainly includes community animals.
 
Designated spots for feeding community animals inside Mantralaya premises must be allocated in accordance with the purpose and intent of the Animal Welfare Board of India‚Äôs circular dated 26 February 2015. Feeding creates friendly animals thereby reducing human/animal conflict and cases of dog bites.
 
The Hon‚Äôble Supreme Court of India in its judgment in Animal Welfare Board of India v. A Nagaraja has held that all animals have a fundamental right to live with honour and dignity and lead lives free from cruelty. The imposition of any kind of restriction on the feeding of community animals or their removal or any cruelty inflicted on them would be in direct contravention of this judgment.

#animalrights #animals #lawyer #animalrightsactivist #mantralaya #maharashtra #mumbai #animallaw #ahimsa #compassion #coexist #coexistence #liveandletlive #peace #dogs #cats #community #communityanimals

On 17th October, the 11th day of Israel‚Äôs bombardments on the besieged Gaza Strip, Israel bombed the Al Ahli hospital in Gaza, killing more than 500 people including patients, doctors & those seeking refuge.

Gaza is home to 2.3 million Palestinians (1.1 million children) and is one of the world‚Äôs most densely populated places. Israel has held it under siege for 16 years. In the last 11 days Israel has dropped thousands of bombs on the imprisoned population, estimated to be the equivalent force of a quarter of a nuclear bomb. Human rights experts have also confirmed the use of the internationally-banned weapon, white phosphorus. More than 1,000 children have been killed by these attacks on Gaza and many more injured.

On 15 October 2023, over 800 scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies signed a public statement warning of the possibility of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. Signatories include prominent Holocaust and genocide studies scholars.

‚ÄúAs scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies, we are compelled to sound the alarm about the possibility of the crime of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. We do not do so lightly, recognising the weight of this crime, but the gravity of the current situation demands it.‚Äù

It is with a heavy heart that I write this, especially after spending last night in hospital with my daughter. 

The horrific experience of a helpless parent watching his ill child struggle to breathe made me reflect on the ongoing conflict in Israel and Palestine, and how it is extremely heartbreaking to witness the loss of innocent lives, many of whom are children, the elderly and woman.

I don‚Äôt condone the actions of either side and in my opinion we should advocate for peace, irrespective of any ‚Äúsides.‚Äù

In my opinion, we are all human and we need to start recognising the value of every single life, regardless of nationality or identity.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve covered wars, you know‚Äù ‚Äî Frank West. Thanks to everyone who have reached out to check in on me. It‚Äôs definitely a new environment, but worthwhile to be here to cover the conflict.

‚ÄúWe write in grief as the full force of the world‚Äôs fifth-strongest army rains bombs down on the people of Palestine, that part of Palestine known to the world today as the Gaza Strip. We grieve as we witness unequivocal military, political, and diplomatic support of Western governments for an Israeli aggression unprecedented since 1948. We write in grief today, October 17, as the latest Israel air assault has targeted the Al-Ahli Arabi Baptist Hospital in Gaza City. Thousands of civilians were seeking treatment and shelter from relentless bombardment; the assault has killed at least 500 people, including patients and medical staff. Today, too, Israel struck a United Nations school housing refugees.

We write in grief for the Palestinian and Israeli people who have lost loved ones to the ravages of military conflict. We were filled with dread witnessing Hamas‚Äôs gruesome operation on October 7. That operation and its aftermath has killed 1,300 Israelis and injured another 3,621, with a further estimated 199 or more Israeli hostages ‚Äî both soldiers and civilians ‚Äî and some foreign nationals taken by Hamas. There is no justification for the targeting of civilians in any context. We write in grief for all civilian life.

We witnessed message after message from universities and corporations that populated our inboxes and screens expressing empathy, outrage, and unconditional support for the state of Israel and its people. We witnessed as two battlefields merged in front of us: one, on the ground, where the besieged and enclosed people in the Gaza Strip face relentless and indiscriminate bombardment; and another, in language, where powerful public discourse coalesces around speaking of Palestinian people as ‚Äúhuman animals.‚Äù U.S. politicians have called for the ‚Äúeradication‚Äù of Palestinians and to ‚Äúlevel‚Äù the Gaza Strip. The rising rhetoric of ‚Äúbarbarism‚Äù and ‚Äúterrorism‚Äù speeded the message that Israeli and U.S. generals and politicians alike relayed: There are no innocent civilians in Gaza.‚Äù

For the full opinion piece, click on the link in our bio or visit independent.com.

In the backdrop of World War II, the heroic contributions of Sikh regiments shine brightly. The 4th Battalion of the 11th Sikh Regiment etched their names in history with their valiant and strategic actions. Their entry into Derna, Libya, in 1942, following the successful recapture of the city from German forces, stands as a testament to the extraordinary courage and unwavering commitment of Sikh soldiers during this global conflict.

Our privilege, our apathy, our superficiality, our jadedness...all of these are toxins from modern society. Do not drink the poison of these synthetically lit times. Take your seat in the web of Life. Feed nutrients through the soil to the hurting trees in the forest.
Spread the word of Love and collective liberation like spores through the air. Let us root in the ecosystem as a dignified human species again‚Ä¶ There is no fear, story, or history that justifies the mass murder of thousands of children. I urge my peers not to stay silent. Do not go on with content as usual. May this liberation effort in Palestine be a ripple effect for all others suffering at the hands of violence and oppression in our world. From this death and decay, may the light of a deeper interwoven humanity step forward. 

Let me make sure to clarify something‚Äôs here:
- ÔøΩI do not condone the actions of Hamas.
- ÔøΩIt was a horrific retaliation to FOthe occupation.
- ÔøΩI am in support of the release of Israeli hostages.
- ÔøΩI believe in a dual-state solution to this conflict where innocent Israelis and Palestinians may live and breathe in equal peace.
- ÔøΩThere is no justification for genocide. Please if you‚Äôd like, try to convince your own heart of otherwise.

text:
President Joe Biden touched down in Israel on Wednesday for a diplomatic scramble to prevent the war with Hamas from spiraling into an even larger conflict, a challenge that became more difficult as outrage swept through the Middle East over an explosion that killed hundreds in a Gaza Strip hospital.

Biden was originally scheduled to visit Jordan as well, but his meetings with Arab leaders were called off as he was leaving Washington, costing him an opportunity for the face-to-face conversations that he views as crucial for navigating this fraught moment.

Now Biden‚Äôs only stop is Tel Aviv, where he‚Äôs expected to push for allowing critical humanitarian aid into Gaza during meetings with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Israel has been preparing for a potential ground invasion of Gaza in response to Hamas‚Äô attacks on Oct. 7, which killed 1,400 Israelis.

üé® As artists and cultural producers, our work has the power to shape public opinion. Today, as the media wages a war against truth and strips this conflict of its historical context, we have a unique responsibility to use our voice and artistic practices to say NO MORE!
Now is the time to protest apartheid and amplify the just cause of the Palestinian people and their resistance against 75 years of occupation.

Artists and cultural workers, join us in standing firmly on the side of the oppressed. We say DOWN WITH OCCUPATION, UP WITH LIBERATION!

What happened: US President Joe Biden visited Tel Aviv in Israel amid the ongoing conflict with Hamas, signaling a significant diplomatic move during the crisis. His arrival took place against the backdrop of a surprise attack by Hamas on Israel and Israel's counteroffensive launched on October 7. During a bilateral meeting with Netanyahu, Biden told him that the blast at the Al-Ahil in Gaza hospital appeared to have been done by the other team and not you".

Details: During a bilateral meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, President Biden emphasized the United States' commitment to supporting Israel and ensuring the nation has the necessary resources for self-defense. Notably, Biden commented on the recent blast at the al-Ahli hospital in Gaza, suggesting that it appeared to be the result of actions by a group distinct from Israel, alluding to the complexity and challenges of the ongoing conflict in the region.

Sri Lankan Parliament to debate Gaza conflict on Friday?

The Sri Lankan Parliament is likely to debate the Gaza conflict on Friday October 20, 2023, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena said today.

The Speaker who responded to a request by several MPs said party leaders will make the final decision on the matter today.

Venerable Athuraliye Rathana Thero, Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa and MP Udaya Gammanpila requested that the House take up a debate on the matter while the government should inform the House on the steps taken to minimize the effects that Sri Lanka could suffer as a result of the conflict.

The Path to Peace: Presenting Asian Paints Miss Universe Nepal 2023 National Costume ‚ú® 

A world flawed by conflict often leads us to confine the dove, symbolizing peace, within a cage. However, it is high time we free the essence of peace and contain the destructive power of missiles instead. 

We are translating this powerful concept into an artistic costume, aiming to convey a profound message of peace, a sentiment deeply ingrained in Nepal's identity as a peace-loving nation. Nepal represents peace through its longstanding commitment to non-violence, its peaceful coexistence with diverse cultures, and its status as a neutral and harmonious nation. 

The costume is meticulously designed in colors that resonate with the choices of peace advocates, symbolizing their unwavering commitment to the cause of peace. ‚òÆÔ∏è

Fears of conflict with Israel have grown in Lebanon following the exchange of missiles.
Observers are concerned that Hezbollah's participation in the conflict against Israel would devastate Lebanon and escalate regional tensions.

in July 2006, Hezbollah seized two Israeli soldiers on its border, leading to a significant military response from Israel. The conflict endured for 34 days and resulted in the loss of approximately 1,100 Lebanese lives and 165 Israelis.

In a maze of shrimp farms, fish ponds and rice fields, fishing cats must tread carefully. In southern Thailand, a fragmented, increasingly human-dominated landscape can lead to human-cat conflict over livestock. Our Panthera Thailand team is actively protecting fishing cats, which are listed as "Vulnerable" by the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.

To tackle this challenge head-on, our team has activated a five-year action plan for the species. The team has now fitted 11 fishing cats with GPS collars to better understand their movement. They've also surveyed local people to get a better sense of the conflict between humans and fishing cats, which has helped them design educational programs intended to promote peaceful coexistence between humans and their feline neighbors. 

üëâLearn more about our comprehensive approach to protecting this rare but vital wild cat species via the link in our bio.

The atrocities unfolding
in Gaza are horrific.

My heart breaks.
My mind breaks.

I am so sorry for all of this death, grief
and irreversible tragedy for Palestinians and Israelis.

I‚Äôm aching everyday, seeing a growing war that has been lingering for years‚Ä¶an uproar due to poking the most fragile conflict that lives at the seed of humanities pain, dehumanization, corruption and violence.

The more I open to learn about the complexities at play, a conflict that has way more sides in the mix that lurk in the shadows, what I find is an unimaginable mess, with different power agendas in every direction.

I am barely sharing what people are posting. This is because I continue to find over simplified perspectives on a situation that is the most nuanced and complex geopolitical and spiritual tension of our time that stretches back way more than 75 years.

I stand for a safe and free Palestine.
I stand for a safe and free Israel.
I stand for the Israeli government
occupation to back the fuck up.

It is disheartening and haunting to see world powers exploiting innocent people and this fragility in the Middle East for their interests.

The more we allow this conflict and the social media wars to separate us, the more we play into the hands of those powers who seek to divide us.
Question your assumptions.

There is no simple answer. I‚Äôm sorry, it really just isn't that simple despite the deep emotional agony, the yearning for an obvious answer, and to find resolution.

This is utterly fucked, and there is no one direction at fault. The game being played by world powers is bigger. than we can imagine.

Stay together.
Heal the wars inside ourselves.
Tend your heart and loved ones.

#freepalestine #endtheoccupation #prayforpeace #heartbreak

Yesterday, the 11th day of Israel‚Äôs bombardment of the besieged Gaza Strip, Israel bombed the Al Ahli hospital in Gaza, killing more than 1000 people including patients, doctors & those seeking refuge.

Gaza is home to 2.3 million Palestinians (1.1 million children) and is one of the world‚Äôs most densely populated places. Israel has held it under siege for 17 years. In the last 11 days Israel has dropped thousands of bombs on the imprisoned population, estimated to be the equivalent force of a quarter of a nuclear bomb. Human rights experts have also confirmed the use of the internationally-banned weapon, white phosphorus.

POLICE AWARE OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES ORGANISED IN RELATION OF ISRAEL CONFLICT

The Police are aware of events and public assemblies being organised in relation to the Israel-Hamas conflict. The National Parks Board (NParks) has also received applications to use the Speakers‚Äô Corner for events related to the Israel-Hamas conflict.

The Police have assessed that there are public safety and security concerns associated with such events, given the heightened tensions. NParks shares the same concerns. There have been numerous incidents of violence reported in many countries amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict. For instance, an Israeli staff from the Israeli Embassy in Beijing was stabbed in front of a supermarket, and a teacher was fatally stabbed by a Chechen individual in France. The peace and harmony between different races and religions in Singapore should not be taken for granted, and we must not let events happening externally affect the internal situation within Singapore. Given the sensitivity of the topic and the volatility of the situation overseas, there is a real risk that such events could give rise to public disorder. As such, applications to hold such events will be turned down.

The Police would like to remind members of the public that public assemblies in Singapore are regulated under the Public Order Act 2009, and that organising or participating in a public assembly without a Police permit in Singapore constitutes an offence under the Public Order Act 2009. The Police will not grant any permit for assemblies that advocate political causes of other countries or foreign entities, or may have the potential to stir emotions and lead to public order incidents.

The Police would also like to remind members of the public to engage in responsible and respectful discussions on this topic, online or otherwise, and avoid making insensitive or offensive remarks about race or religion, which may threaten Singapore‚Äôs racial and religious harmony.

My dear 20‚Äôs,
Your chapters could fill a library. I dipped my toes in every genre: romance, tragedy, comedy, adventure, and places and events so surreal it felt like sci-fi. 

There were near death experiences, natural disasters, world travel, wild animals, heroic rescue missions, maybe a sprinkling of breaking the law‚Ä¶
 I danced, and loved deeply, and made lasting artwork and impressions. I saw all 50 states, and 20 different countries and collected memories and scars.

In the months leading up to turning 30, many many people had comments about it being a turning point, an end, time to settle down, to slow. But every day of my 20s I was just picking up speed hitting my stride. There was a time where I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd make it to 18, or 21, or 25‚Ä¶times where maybe I didn‚Äôt even want to. But now I‚Äôm grateful for every day. A new high score, and 30 feels more like a beginning. 

I‚Äôm going into 30 without some of the traditional markers of success that feel as though they‚Äôre expected, but after 3 decades I‚Äôve realized my definition of success is different than the status quo. 

I am grateful for the people I‚Äôve loved, each one taught me lessons and skills and I carry pieces of them with me. 

I am grateful to be so close with my mother, and for the determination and bravery I inherited from her. I am also grateful for the wandering soul and adventurous spirit I take from my father. Being two different halves, one that‚Äôs is so stable and strong for others like a lighthouse anchored in one place, and one that yearns to explore and take flight and follow where the wind blows, has been a constant conflict for me. Sometimes I feel like I cannot connect or fit quite right anywhere. 

My goal for the next 30 years is to keep living authentically to myself. Keep being wild, and loving wild things. To keep being eccentric and enthusiastic and not become jaded, and to keep doing the things that scare me. 

(This photoshoot was an adventure that involved a 15 mile hike and mild hypothermia with 45mph winds and Ice In a dressüòÇ)

The Inspector-General of Police, Ag. IGP Kayode Adeolu Egbetokun Ph.D, NPM, has, on the 17th of October, 2023, convened a high-powered inter-agency consultative security meeting at the Louis Edet House, Force Headquarters Abuja. The meeting was organized in preparation for the off-season elections scheduled for November 11, 2023, in Bayelsa, Kogi, and Imo States.

Representing the IGP at the event was the Deputy Inspector-General of Police in charge of operations, DIG Ede Ayuba, who underlined the paramount significance of cross-fertilizing ideas among various security and law enforcement agencies towards election security. The goal is to develop collaborative strategies that will ensure the upcoming elections are secure, free, fair, and credible.

In attendance were senior officers representing the leadership of various security and law enforcement agencies involved in election security. These included  representatives of the Service Chiefs (CDS, CoAS, CoNS, and CoAFS)  Chief of Defence Intelligence CDI, DG DSS, DG NIA, CG NIS, CG NSCDC, CG NCS, CG correctional Services, CG Federal Fire Service, and DG NDLEA.

DIG Ede Ayuba praised the collaborative efforts of the armed forces and other sister law enforcement agencies, highlighting their role in fostering unity and contributing to the success of past general elections. The meeting was identified as one among a series of brainstorming sessions outlined by the Force, aimed at securing the forthcoming off-season elections on November 11, 2023.

The meeting, which will be continuous till after the forthcoming guber elections in the 3 affected states, encompassed a range of topics, reflecting the diverse considerations of election security, including an in-depth analysis of potential threats and vulnerabilities in Bayelsa, Kogi, and Imo States, Intelligence Sharing, Logistical Planning, Conflict Prevention, Technology and Innovations as well as manpower deployment.

An American epic Western film¬†that is set in the 1920. After oil brought a fortune to the Native Osage Nation, it attracted the white Americans, who manipulated, extorted, and stole as much Osage money as they could before resorting to numerous murders. Starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Robert De Niro, and Lily Gladstone.

ùêåùêò ùêëùêÑùêïùêàùêÑùêñ:
THIS IS CINEMA !!! My most awaited film of 2023 is here. Martin Scorsese is back with another masterpiece with his 2 beloved actors De Niro & Dicaprio, combining his crime expertise and injecting it into a western genre, and the result is DAMNNNNNNNNN. I CANT BELIEVE WHAT I JUST WITNESSED.

The film highlights the story of the Osages where they are being hunted by the white Americans 1 by 1. Highligting greed, corruption, and manipulation above everything else. It is a traumatic truth that was so painful to see. Thanks Scorsese for highlighting this important history for us.

There have been talks about the 3 hours runtime, but no minutes can be taken off here. Each & every scene fits their purpose. From the introduction of the characters, to the conflict, to the intense situation, and to the resolution. I love the structure as it absorbs us into the film.

Performance wise the 3 main cast nailed their roles, but it was Lily Gladstone that stole the show. Through her we can see a woman that went through pain, hopelessness, and desperation. Let's give Lily all the awards for this role, she deserves it.

This is a must watch film for those looking for peak cinema. Scorsese simply nailed every aspects of filmmaking and it feels personal too, especialy that artistic ending that feels like a love letter to cinema. Perhaps one of the finest films that I've seen.

2023 will go down as the contest between 'Oppenheimer' and 'Killers of Flower Moon', and regardless which side you are on, cinema wins (not theme park movies). This is the kind of film that shows what real cinema is, those layers, depths, and meanings.

Scorsese the living üêê

Free Palestine ~ Over the past few days, with help from this community, I have been educating myself about the conflict between Israel and Palestine.

I cannot continue to do this ancestral work and be in my integrity without taking a very clear stance on this.

I hold compassion for EVERYONE who has been affected by this conflict, who has suffered and been harmed. I grieve deeply for the violence on both sides.

And I cannot claim to walk this decolonial path without clearly stating that I am firmly against Israel as a colonial settler state committing genocide against the Palestinian people.

This conflict didn‚Äôt start this month, it has been going on for 75 years. The Palestinian people have been oppressed by apartheid, denied their basic rights, and have been killed in their fight for freedom.

I am not Palestinian, nor am I Israeli or Jewish. But I am an American whose tax dollars are being used to fund this genocide. If we Americans do not speak out and call our representatives, we are complict. We are colluding with colonial narratives and violence.

It is important for us to speak up in times like this. The more of us that speak up, the more we can normalize standing against colonial agendas and predatory power.

If you‚Äôre an American, you can use the resource in the image to call Congress and demand a ceasefire now. You‚Äôll also find the link in my bio. This resource is provided by Jewish Voice for Peace: @jewishvoiceforpeace.

#FreePalestine

I understand there's a complex history in these lands that's been going on for a very long time. I am not saying that Jews do not have an ancestral claim to these lands. I'm saying that Jews do not have the ONLY claim, and none of the history justifies Palestinians being denied their basic rights.

I condemn Hamas. I support Israel's right to fight terrorism, but there are other ways to deal with terrorists. What's happening in Gaza goes beyond the scope of anti-terrorism and will only cause more extremism, more terrorism, more violence. Killing Hamas at the expense of civilian lives & children will inspire more people to join Hamas.

Israel-Hamas War, Gaza in trouble
The war began on Saturday, October 7, after Hamas infiltrated southern Israel, sending fighters, firing 5,000 rockets, and taking captives, including women, children, and the elderly, which prompted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to warn of ‚Äúa long and difficult war.‚Äú

Since then the Israeli forces have inflicted on the Palestinians several atrocities including cutting off their food, water and power supply. They have also bombed shelters, hospitals and escape routes out of the Gaza Strip and have cornered Palestinians in South Gaza asking them to flee the north as the US-backed army prepares for a ground invasion.

Gaza‚Äôs Ministry of Health said that at least 3,000 Palestinians have been killed, including 1,000 children, and 12,500 citizens injured so far due to Israeli attacks.

In Israel, the number of people killed in Hamas attacks reached 1,400, 302 Israeli soldiers, while more than 3,400 were injured.

In an effort to promote human-wildlife coexistence, @bornfreekenya has been a steadfast partner, implementing a range of innovative and community-centered conservation solutions around Meru National Park. 

One standout initiative is the introduction of beehive fencing, which deters elephants from crop raids in neighbouring community farms. By sponsoring the installation of beehives around the perimeter of the farms, Born Free is not only safeguarding crops but also enabling local farmers to generate additional income through honey production. 

To empower these communities even further, Born Free and KWS actively engage in community meetings, to address human-wildlife conflict issues comprehensively. By working closely with local communities, we aim to find innovative solutions that benefit both wildlife and the residents.

Through this collaborative approach, we envision a future where humans and wildlife coexist in harmony, ensuring the preservation of the natural world for generations to come.

On October 18, 1898 U.S. troops raised the U.S. flag over Puerto Rico, formalizing U.S. authority over the island‚Äôs one million inhabitants during the Spanish-American War.

Read background to this event in the excerpt below from ‚ÄúA Brief History of Puerto Rico‚Äù by Johnny Irizarry, Maria Mills-Torres, Marta Moreno Vega, and Anita Rivera in¬†Caribbean Connections: Puerto Rico:

‚Äú
After 400 years of Spanish domination, the island was now under the control of the United States. . . A new colonial era began in 1898. Puerto Rico was now ruled as a possession of the U.S. Conflict between the people and their new rulers emerged first over language. Illiteracy was widespread at that time, affecting 85 percent of the population, and the U.S. expected no resistance from the Puerto Ricans when it imposed English-only laws on the island. Puerto Rican intellectuals and independentistas (people who fight for Puerto Rican independence) resisted the replacement of the Spanish language with English. From 1898 until the establishment of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico in 1952, U.S. governors maintained some type of English-only law over Puerto Rico. In 1952, Spanish once again became the official language of Puerto Rico ‚Äî although the use of English continues to be required in some educational, governmental and judicial functions.

In 1917 President Woodrow Wilson signed the Jones Act, which made Puerto Ricans citizens of the United States. Those who chose to reject U.S. citizenship would become exiles in their own homeland. Others left the island as a rejection of U.S. domination. U.S. citizenship, extended in the midst of World War I, brought with it the imposition of military service on Puerto Ricans.‚Äù

Teaching for Change's @sojustbooks offers an annotated bibliography of books for children: https://socialjusticebooks.org/puerto-rican-childrens-literature-social-justice-bibliography/

[Image description: Black and white photo shows the U.S. flag raised on October 18, 1898 in San Juan, Puerto Rico.]

The recent outbreak of violence between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza threatens to upend decades of painstaking diplomacy by Morocco to broker peace between the two sides.

In early October 2023, Palestinian militant groups led by Hamas launched Operation Al-Aqsa Flood, firing barrages of rockets at Israeli towns and cities. They said it was in response to ‚ÄúIsraeli violations‚Äù at the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem. Israel responded with punishing airstrikes on Gaza. The fighting marked the worst escalation since the 2014 Gaza war.

For Morocco, the fresh violence represents a major setback. It comes just two years after Morocco agreed to normalize relations with Israel under the Abraham Accords, with the promise of being able to leverage these new ties to advance peace. Now, with tensions inflamed anew, Morocco‚Äôs unique role as a mediator between Israel and the Palestinians faces its biggest test yet.

Morocco‚Äôs involvement in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict dates back to the 1950s and 1960s, when the late King Mohammed V expressed support for Palestinian statehood. In 1965, King Hassan II began actively promoting himself as an intermediary for peace.

Israel has bombed a hospital in Gaza and killed at least 500 people, according to Palestinian officials.

Palestinian authorities said an Israeli airstrike hit the Al-Ahli hospital in Gaza City where civilians had been seeking shelter on Tuesday Oct 17.

The Palestinian Health Ministry said that at least 500 people had been killed.
The ministry said that hundreds of victims remain trapped under the rubble and the death toll is expected to rise

An Israeli military spokesperson said it was ‚Äúchecking‚Äù if it was responsible for the blast.

A later statement from the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) spokesperson said another militant group was responsible for the bombing.

‚ÄúThe hospital was hit as a result of a failed rocket launched by the Islamic Jihad terrorist organization,‚Äù Israel Defense Forces (IDF) spokesperson said.

Islamic Jihad has denied the allegation.

‚ÄúWhat happened tonight is a huge tragedy and war ugly massacre that cannot be tolerated or allowed to pass without accountability,‚Äù Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said and blamed Israel for the airstrike.

The death toll of the incident is the highest since the war started on Oct. 7.

A school run by the United Nations that was housing refugees was also struck earlier in the day, killing six people, according to Al Jazeera.

Since declaring war on Palestinian militant group Hamas, Israel has ordered a complete blockade of Gaza ‚Äì home to more than two million Palestinians ‚Äì blocking food, water and fuel from entering

Israeli airstrikes have killed more than 2,700 Palestinians, nearly 10,000 have been injured and forced hundreds of thousands to flee their homes, according to Reuters.

Food, water and fuel are running low.

Meanwhile, 1,400 Israelis have died and 200 people have been taken hostage by Hamas.

The attack on the hospital came a day before US President Joe Biden was expected to visit Israel. (üì∏: Getty, üìù: @kassy)

The African lion is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN red list of threatened species - their population has decreased by 75% in just five decades. Increasing human populations reduce available lion habitat, leading to a rise in human-lion conflict. Science and research are essential if we are to preserve future lion populations.

The @‚Äåsactrust (SACT), @tkpp_wildcru (TKPP) and Nelson Mandela University require GPS satellite collars to track the natural movement of lions between protected areas and develop lion management plans. These collars provide data to computer simulations that allow TKPP to monitor lion prides situated on park boundaries. They also provide an early-warning system to local communities about the whereabouts of lions and allow them to react quickly to potential problems and avoid human-lion conflict.

Find out more about sponsoring a lion collar and what your sponsorship will include under the 'Collar a lion' tab in our bio link.

Whether the conflict is political, societal, or global, I feel that it is important for us to help hold space for all emotions, opinions, and ways of being.

Over the years, I‚Äôve reflected on ways to create safe space during turbulent times, while recognizing that I am not a licensed therapist. To that end, I wanted to share some of the ways I have learned to show up for students without needing to have answers or inviting anger or conflict into the teaching space. In 1999, @edward.said_ a Palestinian-American author/scholar, and @dbarenboim, an Israeli conductor/pianist, realized the urgent need for an alternative way to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The opportunity to do this came when Barenboim and Said initiated the first workshop using their experience as a model. This evolved into the West-Eastern @divanorchestra that global audiences know today. In a message written on Monday, October 16, and published on West-Eastern Orchestra website, Daniel Barendoim writes: ‚ÄúIn the current situation, we naturally ask ourselves about the significance of our joint work in both the orchestraand the academy. It may seem little-but the mere fact that Arab and Israeli musicians share a podium at every concert and make music together, that is of immense value to us. Over the years, through this commonality of music-making, but also through our countless, sometimes heated discussions, we have learned to better understand the supposed other, to approach them and to find common ground in our humanity and in music. We start and end all discussions, no matter how controversial, with the fundamental understanding that we are all equal human beings who deserve peace, freedom and happiness.‚Äù You can read the full message via the link in our bio. This spirit of empathy and recognition of the integral role music can play in all our lives‚Äîin times of happiness and in times of great tragedy‚Äîis at the core of Princeton University Concerts (PUC) #HealingWithMusic initiatives. If you‚Äôd like to learn more, follow @princetonuniversityconcerts on Instagram or visit https://concerts.princeton.edu/healing-with-music-videos/
Link in @princetonuniversityconcerts for further reading and information.

In the midst of global turmoil, my heart aches for all those facing sadness and conflict. There is a lot of intense energy around us, urging us to come together and make change. As a woman and a healer, I'm moved to share my wisdom more than ever. 

Women, we are the healers, the nurturers, the life-bringers. Our bodies are designed to feel deeply, we need to work with this powerful portal energy. 

But, for too long, our emotions and health issues have been misunderstood, overlooked, or labeled as "crazy" or "hormonal."
¬†
I am here to tell you that you are not alone. You are not crazy. You are a woman, and you possess a remarkable strength and wisdom, that the world needs.

When women fully embrace and understand their innate power, you awaken a boundless energy to give back to the world. These qualities are beautiful + magnetic + transformative üôåüèº 
¬†
For over a decade, I've been working with women 1:1, hosting moon circles, retreats and gatherings. I've witnessed that women are inherently emotional, deeply sensitive, and cyclical beings. 

Our bodies naturally sync with the moon cycle, and when women come together, change takes place. In this safe and nurturing space, women can express their true selves, feel seen, heard, and held. 

This is why I am deeply passionate about leading my first women‚Äôs group program, Nourish Your Flow - 8 Week Course - starting October 28th. 

It's not just about understanding your body, loving it, and embracing its superpower‚Äîyour period. It's about the power of women gathering in a supportive group of environment. 

Where women can feel safe, share, connect, learn, grow, and ultimately be nourished.¬†

From this place, we can create change! 

I care so deeply about this work.

The countdown is on, I would love to have you join the brave women who are already signed up to join this journey. 

We are less than 2 weeks away - sign up links in my BIO ‚òùüèº 

I am sending my love, prayer and hope for everyone who is dealing with grief and hopelessness right now. You are not alone!¬†
¬†
All my love + light,
Aimee-Jean x

Official Communication from AIESEC in Bahrain: Serving our mission with integrity

Dear AIESECers, partners, and supporters,

In AIESEC in Bahrain, our mission is clear: to develop the leadership potential of young people. We firmly believe that leadership is not merely a position or a title; it's a way of being. It's about positively impacting society, advocating for what's right, and standing up for one's beliefs. We stand in solidarity with the civilian victims in Palestine and call on young people around the world to educate themselves about the ongoing crisis and take a stand against human rights violations.

We stand with those who strive for a world where everyone is treated equitably and where every voice is heard. We believe that our role as value-driven leaders is to lead by example, uphold our values, and support what's right.

We stand against violence and aggression that endanger the safety and rights of the apartheid victims. We firmly believe that justice should prevail, and while we may not have the means to directly influence global conflicts, we can offer our support, compassion, and efforts to alleviate the suffering of those affected by speaking up for their rights.

" Call to Action: We urge all members of AIESEC in the Bahrain community and all our stakeholders in the Bahraini society to join us in supporting the victims in Palestine. Let us heed the call from our government, make donations, and take actions that can make a real difference in the lives of those in need in Palestine. As Bahrainis, let us prioritize action and leadership in these challenging times, reaffirming our commitment to a better world for all.

In a world where division and conflict persist, we stand united in our mission to contribute to a more just, equitable, and just global community.

#AIESECinBahrain #standingforwhatsright #valuedrivenleadership

PRESS RELEASE

STRENGTHENING NIGERIA LAW ENFORCEMENT: IGP ENGAGES US SENIOR ADVISOR SHAUN J. GAVIN, DISCUSSES AREAS OF PARTNERSHIP ON SPECIAL INTERVENTION SQUAD 

In a landmark meeting on monday, October 16th at the Hilton Bayfront, San Diego, the Inspector General of Police, IGP Kayode Adeolu Egbetokun, NPM, Ph.D., engaged in further purposive discussions with Senior Advisor Shaun J. Gavin, representing the International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs (INL) of the United States Embassy in Abuja. The focus of the dialogue centred on fortifying the collaboration between the two nations in the realm of law enforcement, particularly concerning the establishment and operationalization of the Special Intervention Squad (SIS).

Expressing mutual commitment, the IGP and Senior Advisor Shaun J. Gavin deliberated on key areas of partnership aimed at bolstering the SIS. The SIS, a crucial initiative of the IGP, signifies a specialized response to prevailing security challenges, with a keen focus on regions grappling with conflict and terrorist threats. The meeting emphasized the strategic importance of this collaboration in enhancing the capabilities of the Nigeria Police Force and contributing to regional stability.

Tracing the bond between the Transitional Police Unit (TPU) and the Special Intervention Squad (SIS), this collaboration addresses critical gaps in regions facing conflict and terrorist threats. Senior Advisor Shaun J. Gavin's leadership emphasizes the SIS's vital role in augmenting the capacity of the Armed Forces of Nigeria, ensuring a strategic and specialized response. This partnership not only aligns with the broader national security objectives but also signifies a milestone in the deepening bilateral ties between the U.S. and Nigeria.

ACP OLUMUYIWA ADEJOBI, mnipr, mipra,
FORCE PUBLIC RELATIONS OFFICER,
FORCE HEADQUARTERS,
ABUJA.

18th October 2023

He said that he settled abroad in 1992. After his family faced a robbery attempt and guns were pointed at his children, he decided to leave Pakistan.

The primordial healing traditions of the world vary in many ways, but one core belief they all share is that everything inside of us possesses an energy or spiritual charge. Feelings of negativity aren't dismissed or coped with in these cultures; they are worked with and cleared, often through the ritualistic burning of herbs or plant resins.

If you feel stuck, stressed, overwhelmed, blocked, low energy, or laden with inner conflict in your life, this ancient method of clearing the air is definitely something to try.

Combining the right intentions with specific herbs can make for a powerful ritual.

Below, I‚Äôm going to share three shamanic ceremonial herbs that are perfect to use for space clearing and how best to use them all together.

1. Use Sage to clear

Sage is a wonderful purification herb that can be used in your home, workspace, automobile, or any other place you spend time in. I like to use sage, known by the scientific name Salvia officinalis, when I'm traveling to cleanse hotel rooms before I settle in.

We burn it after having guests over, to reset the space and send everyone's energies along with them. For anyone working in healing arts, sage is especially important to use after each session, to purify the healing environment between clients.

To start working with this herb, open a window or a door and then slowly walk through each room with a piece of burning sage, allowing the smoke to spread over all the surfaces. Try setting the intention of clearing, releasing, and letting go of anything that no longer serves you, or that doesn‚Äôt belong.

"I release attachment to anything that does not serve my highest and best self."

‚ÄúI let go of any negative thoughts, worries, or any energy that does not...

Click the link in bio to continue reading this on our blog OR:

https://www.thesacredscience.com/3-shamanic-ceremonial-herbs-for-creating-sacred-space/

... cont. Thanks to those who have messaged telling us about some great conversations happening and plans to ease the mental load of many mammas.
Also, I know that many dads worry about their kids - of course they do! Statistics indicate though that women are more prone to anxious thinking than men. Some research has shown, too, that women are more likely to ruminate than men.
And, what I was pointing out to Kate in the Nova interview was not to say that women love their kids more than men. Or that worry makes a better parent... This is just a dynamic that commonly plays out in a lot of heterosexual relationships. And it can create conflict, which could be resolved with honest, real conversations.
This chat has obviously struck a chord about potential challenges for those practising ‚Äòteam parenting' and that's a good thing! Exploring how to be the dad you want to be - especially if you had an old school dad - is certainly something some of the dads I've interviewed for the @listnrau podcast, The Good Enough Dad, have been talking about. And I look forward to hearing more from them to keep this conversation going.  And please see link@in my bio for podcast link and an article on soothing mama stress and angst.

U.S. President Joe Biden arrived in Israel on Oct. 18 in a show of support for the country amid the conflict with Hamas,¬†supporting¬†Tel Aviv's account of the Gaza hospital explosion a day earlier.

"I was deeply saddened and outraged by the explosion of the hospital in Gaza yesterday, and based on what I've seen, it was done by the 'other team' and not you," Biden said during a press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

Hamas-run Gaza Health Ministry¬†said¬†on Oct. 17 that hundreds of people had been killed in an Israeli strike against the Al-Ahli Baptist Hospital in Gaza.

Israel "categorically" denied the accusation, saying that the hospital was hit by a rocket misfired by Islamic Jihad, a radical Palestinian militant group. Israeli authorities later published¬†footage¬†which they say proves their account of the event.

The Communist Party of Sri Lanka (CPSL), issuing a statement, expressed what it calls ‚Äòunwavering solidarity‚Äô with the Palestinian people during this period of increased resistance to Israel's criminal occupation of Palestinian territory.

The statement said the CPSL places the full responsibility on the fascist right-wing government of Israel for the sharp and dangerous escalation that has resulted in many innocent civilians losing their lives.

"At the end of a shocking week in early October, in which the settlers ran amok throughout the occupied territories under the auspices of the Israeli government and incidents around the Al-Aqsa Mosque led to the very serious escalation.

‚ÄúThe deaths of civilians and crimes against them on both sides must be avoided and condemned. However, it must be clearly understood that horrific crimes are perpetrated against the Palestinian people on a daily basis by the Israeli military and state-backed settlers.

"The Communist Party of Sri Lanka strongly and unequivocally condemn the continued military bombardment on Gaza which has resulted in the killing of scores of Palestinian civilians and injuring of hundreds more including children.

Collective punishment of the people of Gaza is a war crime and must cease immediately. Israel‚Äôs brazen violation of international humanitarian law and international law has continued for decades now, with the full support of imperialist forces, and without any meaningful intervention to address the core issue of the conflict.

"The CPSL would like to emphasize that the core issue of the conflict will only be resolved by implementing the resolution adopted by the United Nations Security Council.

This year, our International Competition presents 11 films that explore contemporary conflict and turmoil through deeply personal experiences. 

With 17 countries represented, the selection takes us on a profound journey through the harsh realities of the most tumultuous conflicts of our time‚Äîfrom Gaza to Myanmar to Nagorno-Karabakh. By revisiting archives and engaging in recent debates, several filmmakers take to the critical re-examination of our established recounts of history. With the ever-rising urgency of climate crisis, a number of selected filmmakers turn their attention to the rapidly unfolding consequences to our natural world.

What values do you bring to F&M? What does belonging mean to you? On the first day of F&M Inclusion Week, students, faculty and staff gathered in a sharing circle hosted by the College‚Äôs new Conflict Transformers facilitation team. Each member shared their experience of belonging at F&M and discussed how members of the campus community can create an inclusive environment. 

Focusing on the theme ‚ÄúVitality at F&M: Feeling Value & Worth,‚Äù Inclusion Week offers 23 distinct programs and workshops proposed and organized by various clubs, organizations and offices across campus. Events include spoken word performance art, stand-up comedy, community discussions and one-on-one conversations.

For a complete schedule, see the link in our bio for the Ampersand calendar or @fandmdei on Instagram.

We are delighted to share that our Doctoral Fellow, Simran Prasad has won the ‚ÄúBest Speed Talk‚Äù award at the Student Conference for Conservation Science (SCCS), New York, on the 6th of October, 2023. The talk was presented virtually under the session titled ‚ÄúHumans and Wildlife‚Äù, and organized by the Center for Biodiversity and Conservation at the American Museum of Natural History. The title of the talk was ‚ÄòHuman injury and death: a global review on understudied aspects of wildlife conflict‚Äô and was focused on her research on human casualties during wildlife conflict events across the world. 

Simran is conducting extensive research on interactions between people and wildlife within the Western Ghats to unpack the nuances within the relationship. Please donate at the link in our bio to help support Simran‚Äôs research as she continues to study these fascinating interactions. Thank you!

Several dozen people attended a Fairhope Library Board meeting Monday afternoon after months of conflict over books with LGBTQ themes and their place in the library‚Äôs catalog.

After the room reached its 25-person capacity, many attendees stood in the hall, observing the meeting through the doorway and stepping in to speak one by one.

The library board meeting came highly anticipated by advocates after a contentious Fairhope city council meeting last month drew more than 100 people concerned about the library. 

That meeting concluded with Jay Robinson, the president of the city council informing residents that, while the council was appreciative of the civic engagement, library book selection is an issue for the library board.

Many of the people who attended that council meeting showed up at the library board on Monday.

Go to the link in our bio to read what attendees had to say.

On 17th October, the 11th day of Israel‚Äôs bombardments on the besieged Gaza Strip, Israel bombed the Al Ahli hospital in Gaza, killing more than 500 people including patients, doctors & those seeking refuge.

Gaza is home to 2.3 million Palestinians (1.1 million children) and is one of the world‚Äôs most densely populated places. Israel has held it under siege for 17 years. In the last 11 days Israel has dropped thousands of bombs on the imprisoned population, estimated to be the equivalent force of a quarter of a nuclear bomb. Human rights experts have also confirmed the use of the internationally-banned weapon, white phosphorus.

On 15 October 2023, over 800 scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies signed a public statement warning of the possibility of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. Signatories include prominent Holocaust and genocide studies scholars.

‚ÄúAs scholars and practitioners of international law, conflict studies and genocide studies, we are compelled to sound the alarm about the possibility of the crime of genocide being perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. We do not do so lightly, recognising the weight of this crime, but the gravity of the current situation demands it.‚Äù

Official Communication from AIESEC in Bahrain: Serving our mission with integrity

Dear AIESECers, partners, and supporters,

In AIESEC in Bahrain, our mission is clear: to develop the leadership potential of young people. We firmly believe that leadership is not merely a position or a title; it's a way of being. It's about positively impacting society, advocating for what's right, and standing up for one's beliefs. We stand in solidarity with the civilian victims in Palestine and call on young people around the world to educate themselves about the ongoing crisis and take a stand against human rights violations.

We stand with those who strive for a world where everyone is treated equitably and where every voice is heard. We believe that our role as value-driven leaders is to lead by example, uphold our values, and support what's right.

We stand against violence and aggression that endanger the safety and rights of the apartheid victims. We firmly believe that justice should prevail, and while we may not have the means to directly influence global conflicts, we can offer our support, compassion, and efforts to alleviate the suffering of those affected by speaking up for their rights.

" Call to Action: We urge all members of AIESEC in the Bahrain community and all our stakeholders in the Bahraini society to join us in supporting the victims in Palestine. Let us heed the call from our government, make donations, and take actions that can make a real difference in the lives of those in need in Palestine. As Bahrainis, let us prioritize action and leadership in these challenging times, reaffirming our commitment to a better world for all.

In a world where division and conflict persist, we stand united in our mission to contribute to a more just, equitable, and just global community.

#AIESECinBahrain#ValueDrivenLeadership #raiseyourvoice

I went with J street leadership to Washington today to talk to members of Congress. Thank them for supporting Israel and their unwavering commitment to Israel‚Äôs security and Israelis following the Hamas Massacre and kidnapping and the escalation in the northern border as well as the release the hostages. We asked for immediate humanitarian aid to civilians in Gaza facing relentless bombing and horrifying rising numbers of casualties. Gaza is experiencing a full scale humanitarian catastrophe. No water, no safety, no food, no electricity. No one knows if they will live to see tomorrow. We reiterated our support for President Biden‚Äôs call for Israel to abide by international laws of war. Allow water, food and medicine through a humanitarian corridor and the opening of the Rafah border crossing (with guarantees for Palestinians that come out to ability to return). 
We asked for American leadership to join Arab countries and the international community to resolving the conflict helping to end the occupation and investing and rebuilding Gaza. What was cannot be no more. What was led to this horror. No one is safe. It‚Äôs not just Israeli or Palestinian problem. It‚Äôs an international crisis. 
I pray for the end of this war and terrified from what‚Äôs coming. Biden has a very good team in place. There must be an end game someone can articulate. 
In between meetings the Republican Party tried again to elect a speaker. The House cannot function. Republicans cannot govern. Republicans are preventing appointments of key diplomats and military command. Delaying urgent assistance. Undermining the security of America. And I learned have the power to have all the TV‚Äôs in the cafeteria Fox News. Just like Bibi and his team of criminals they just don‚Äôt care about the people or their country. It‚Äôs the destruction authoritarianism brings. That‚Äôs Trumpism - it drags all of us to hell. 
As we are sitting in the last meeting we heard a hospital in Gaza was bombed killing hundreds of people - this is the collapse of humanity again and again. I went to the bathroom and just cried. 
Every member of Congress in my meetings expressed the importance of our advocacy in this time.

‚ÄúOne of our first learnings of the dynamic between man and elephant happened during our fieldwork in Palakkad, Kerala. We met a man who graciously took us through his fields and showed us his maize plants. Over hot tea and sweetcorn, he told us about the elephants he had seen, having lived on the land for longer than a decade. He explained that he felt deeply connected to the animal, and felt they were a majestic sight to behold. The farmer then took us to a railway track close to his house. Here, he explained that elephants often lose their lives, or face injury due to oncoming trains and collisions. He expressed his fondness for the animal, and sadness when hearing about their pain‚Äù.

Our Doctoral Fellow, Simran Prasad, shares an interesting story about her time in the field. Simran is currently working to understand the challenges that farmer‚Äôs face due to increasing elephant conflict incidents across the Western Ghats. If you want to support Simran‚Äôs work, please donate at the link in our bio to help her research solutions to aid people that face conflict. Thank you!

A Maltese-American media man who reported the Palestinian-Israeli conflict for years is bracing himself for the toughest story of his life, as he seeks cover in the besieged Gaza Strip.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if I will stay alive or not, but please tell my story,‚Äù Qassem Ali told Times of Malta on Tuesday night. 

The 65-year-old‚Äôs call on a faint line from a school in Gaza where he is taking shelter took place just an hour after a hospital was blown up in Gaza, killing hundreds in what appears to be the deadliest attack since Hamas sparked a new bloody uprising. 

Ali said he had been trying to get through to a doctor friend of his who worked at the hospital after the blast, but the line went dead.

Read more at timesofmalta.com or by clicking the link in our bio.

Kelab Bundesliga Jerman itu menyifatkan tindakan El-Ghazi "tidak boleh diterima kelab" serta tidak "sejajar dengan nilai-nilai kelab".

Memetik laporan Al Jazeera, pemain bola sepak itu memuat naik ayat berbunyi 'Palestine will be free' (Palestin akan bebas).

Bagaimanapun, bekas pemain sayap Aston Villa, El Ghazi sudah memadam hantaran itu.

El-Ghazi, yang berasal dari Maghribi mewakili Belanda dua kali, menandatangani untuk Mainz pada akhir September.

El-Ghazi sebelum ini telah bermain untuk gergasi Belanda PSV Eindhoven dan Ajax, serta kelab Liga Perdana Aston Villa dan Everton.

Rakyat Palestin di Jerman, serta penyokong turut menerima sekatan dan tidak membenarkan mereka yang pro-Palestin untuk mengecam tindakan Israel dan membuat protes di negara itu.

"Mainz menghormati terdapat perspektif berbeza mengenai konflik Timur Tengah yang berlaku selama beberapa dekad," kata kelab itu dalam satu kenyataan yang disiarkan di Twitter.

MERCY Malaysia strongly condemns Israel's recent strike on Al-Ahli Baptist Arab Hospital in Gaza, which claimed the lives of 500 people. 

This reprehensible act not only resulted in the loss of innocent lives but also violated the fundamental principles of International Humanitarian Law. Hospitals, along with other medical facilities, must remain sanctuaries in times of conflict to provide life-saving medical care to those in need.

This is a stark reminder of the importance of adhering to the rules of war as outlined in the Geneva Conventions. Hospitals and healthcare workers should never be targeted, and those injured in conflict must have access to the medical care they need. MERCY Malaysia calls for an immediate end to any attacks on hospitals, medical personnel, and healthcare infrastructure.

MERCY Malaysia stands in solidarity with the people affected by the recent strike on the hospital in Gaza. We reiterate our call for the protection of hospitals in accordance with International Humanitarian Law and for an immediate end to attacks on healthcare facilities.

Our thoughts are with the victims and their families. Let us remember that wars should never be fought at the expense of innocent lives and the sanctity of hospitals. It is our collective responsibility to ensure that healthcare remains accessible and safe for all, regardless of the circumstances.

#MERCYForAll #Palestine #alahlihospital #Gaza

While speaking in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Wednesday, President Joe Biden warned Israeli leadership not to be ‚Äúconsumed‚Äù by rage and to learn from the ‚Äúmistakes‚Äù made by the United States in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.

Biden‚Äôs Warning: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure those horrors have tapped into some kind of primal feeling in Israel just like it did in the United States,‚Äù Biden stated. ‚ÄúShock, pain, rage. An all-consuming rage.‚Äù Biden went on to say, ‚ÄúJustice must be done. But I caution this: While you feel that rage, don‚Äôt be consumed by it. After 9/11 we were enraged in the United States. While we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes.‚Äù

Bipartisan Regret: Biden‚Äôs warning comes the same day as the release of an AP-NORC poll, which concluded that a majority of both Democrats and Republicans believe America‚Äôs war in Afghanistan ‚Äî a war started in response to the 9/11 attacks ‚Äî was not worth fighting. Only 29% stated that the U.S. succeeded in ‚Äúeliminating the threat from Islamic extremists taking shelter in Afghanistan.‚Äù

Gaza Endgame: Echoing American frustration with the two-decade-long conflict in Afghanistan, Reuters (Center bias) is reporting that Israeli officials have ‚Äúno obvious endgame in sight, with no clear plan for how to govern the ravaged Palestinian enclave even if it triumphs on the battlefield.‚Äù Israeli officials reportedly ‚Äúdon't have a clear idea for what a post-war future might look like‚Äù for Gaza.

BREAKING NEWS
United posted really good Q3 earnings last night but is getting hammered thanks to more pessimistic Q4 guidance from the airline. 

WHAT HAPPENED
For Q3, United experienced record revenue and profits thanks to low fuel costs and an explosion in international travel. United performed even better than the market expected, hitting $14.4 billion in revenue and a near 10% EPS beat of $3.65. But this market is forward-looking, so United's guidance is what investors really wanted to see. 

WHAT'S COMING NEXT
And United is expecting to get hammered from multiple angles. First up, they are being hit with much higher expected fuel costs than their competitors, expecting an 11% increase in costs from Q3 that will absolutely bulldoze their ability to profit. 

Meanwhile, United is one of the most exposed U.S. airlines to the ongoing conflict in Israel, with service to Tel Aviv from 3 airports in their coverage. If they keep flights paused, United expects a massive additional decline in EPS, all the way down to $1.50 a share potentially, With Wall Street expecting around $2.09 for Q4, that's a pretty massive deal in a moment where the crisis in Gaza only appears to be deepening. 

WHY IT MATTERS
After boosting profitability through a high-demand Q3, the easier days of summer are gone for airlines. Fuel costs have come roaring back and worldwide uncertainty can put a damper on international travel as well. This is causing a pretty big reversal for airlines right now after Q2 beats drove a wave of bull sentiment. While this won't break United, it can be a strong headwind for the top airline. The market is now much more concerned about weaker companies like American Airlines, which reports earnings tomorrow. While every airline faltered in early trading, United took the brunt of the selloff by dropping over 5% at market open. 

#stocks #stockmarket #investing #finance

ü§ì Books to help you become the most interesting person in the room

Becoming the most interesting person in the room isn't just about what you know. It's also about being genuinely curious, a good listener, and openess to learning from others.

Here are some books across different genres/topics that can help you on your journey to becoming a fascinating conversationalist:

(1) Quiet - The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking by Susan Cain

Understand the strengths and unique qualities of introverts in an extroverted world. Discover more about yourself and how you interact with others.

(2) Thinking, Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman

An exploration of cognitive psychology and decision-making that can enhance your critical thinking skills and that of others.

(3) Good Economics for Hard Times: Better Answers to Our Biggest Problems by Abhijit V. Banerjee and Esther Duflo

A thorough examination utilizing economics to address pressing societal challenges today such as slow economic growth, income inequality, immigration, climate change & more.

(4) The Art of War by Sun Tzu

Ah, a classic! Timeless wisdom on strategy, leadership, and conflict resolution that can be applied to various aspects of one's life or business.

(5) Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind by Yuval Noah Harari

A thought-provoking exploration of the history of our species, offering insights into human behavior and society. But hey, if it gets too dry for your liking, check out the graphic adaptation instead.

Now go forth and make some new friends and strike up great conversations‚ùó

PS Any more books you would add to the list‚ùì
